content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Even today, KOTOR I stands as an excellent example of what an RPG can be, and strongly breaks the assertion that all movie-licensed video games are terrible and cash-grabs. It isn't just a great RPG or a great entry of the Star Wars universe, but is also and quite simply a great video game that can be enjoyed by a wider audience than just RPG and Star Wars fans. Story is an EXTREMLY important part of this game, and a highlight to that as well. You are a Republic soldier on a ship called the Endar Spire, and your goal is to escape before the Sith destroy it. You crash land on the planet Taris, and your adventure unfolds through exploration, character-development, and revelation. Choice is present in this game as well, adding replay-value as well. I cannot give away much about the story without spoiling the game, and it is best to experience it for yourself. Personally, I had no qualms with it, and the game stays true to the Star Wars universe while adding flavours of its own. The setting of 4000 years prior to the movies also makes it so you can appreciate the story without any past knowledge of Star Wars. I would even dare to say that this game easily triumphs over the stories of the movies.How about gameplay? It is a turn-based game with many different weapons (from ranged to melee), powers and abilities that can be disposed against the enemy, and thankfully this game has a lot of different foes to defeat. The layers of strategy are quite endless, as you always have two squad-mates present at any time. Do you charge into battle while they cover you with gun-fire? Do you all throw grenades to make quick work of your foes? Difficulty options are also present, which are nice as some weapon configurations can allow you to be a god while others will leave you crying for mercy. Luckily with squad-mates, this is really a non-issue. There are also side activities, called swoop racing and pazzak, which are fun side games that provide replayability.Also a side note, but combat can be paused to issue commands, and you watch the action unfold. Modifiers can allow you to deal more/less damage, and you can even miss, as the game has a dice-roll mechanic in its turn-based formula.As for graphics, the game is clearly dated by today's standards. In terms of art style, this game is spot on. It retains Star Wars' signature look and style, and developer BioWare has added their own flair and style to it, making the game stand out in this department, and being memorable to that. This can also be said for the sound, which is indentical to what you would expect from the franchise. Lasers to lightsabers all sound spot-on, and both the soundtrack and voice work are fantastic as well. In terms of replayability, the great story and presence of choice already make it a game that you can put multiple playthroughs into. There are also many side quests and lore that you can delve into, and maybe you'll see something that you didn't see before on a second or third playthrough. Even the gameplay can offer up different experiences depending on how you play. My run of the game was about 31 hours, and this was ignoring most side-quests, so you will find your money's worth at $10.99, especially if this game goes on sale. Honestly, this is one of few games I can say I didn't have any personal issues with. Others may differ in opinion, but to me KOTOR was flawless. If you're a Star Wars or RPG fan, this game is a MUST BUY. I'd strongly reccomend it to anyone, however the combat mechanics may turn some off, especially if you loathe RNG. However, in this particular game it comes off as natural and is perfectly fine, unlike the TES III Morrwind combat system, as it is turn-based. If I had to rate this game out of 10, it would definitely be a 10/10, but like every game it does have mechanics that have the potential to be even better.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
Rank: 9/10Recommendation(s): Like Star Wars, RPG games, and old school game mechanics.Major Theme: This old title shows us how games should be made.Bought at Price: $10.99I have over a thousand hours on Dota 2, 700+ on Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, and more than enough on Garry's Mod. So why would I play this game if I have plenty of hours on my other games? There's a simple reason for this.Bioware. Yes, the timely company turned EA division, makes this game great.While this game will prove a challenge for people who want non-stop action, this classic title has to be one of the most solid RPG games, if not PC titles ever made. Before I got a Steam account, I played this game with CDs (yes real CDs).There's actual content to the story, and the plot is well thought out and executed. Your actions will have consequences, and will either lead you down to the light or dark side of the force. Beyond just simple dark vs. light, the game offers other ways of having a unique experience. 


STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™ 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™
By: DarK_St3alth




Using your repair and computer skills, you can clear rooms filled with enemies, or fix up and alter a robot to fight for you. Want to avoid enemies? There's a stealth skill for that. Want to avoid fights in a bar? The persuasion skill is your go to skill. Maybe you even want to have the most powerful force powers available to you? There's a way to go about that as well. The only limiting part of the game is base story, which should be entertaining and engaging. It can be a little dry, as there is a lack of humor, but this title does very well considering its ESRB rating (Mass Effect isn't in the same boat).


STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™ 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™
By: DarK_St3alth




As always, it wouldn't be a Bioware game without companions. Each offers something unique, and will progress your back story which isn't mandatory.


STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™ 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™
By: DarK_St3alth




Downsides? Well every game has some which isn't surprising. For being an old title, the graphics are very simple. If you failed to notice the processor requirement of an Intel Pentium 3, then I'm not sure what to say. There's nothing you can really do to improve the graphics of the title, but there are certainly ways to modernize them. By default the game is only compatible with a 4:3 ratio monitor. By using third-party utilities, you can resolve this and get a better experience with a now standard 16:9 monitor.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=427275987Being an old school game, it does have all the “attributes” available. Yes, you will have to micro manage things like points in “wisdom” and “dexterity”. If you want to avoid all of that, play with the “auto upgrade” button. The game does also have a “dice roll” system, where there are chances to miss/hit and not do complete damage. Mass Effect 1 carried on from this, in case you were wondering where that game got its mechanic from.All in all, this title should impress you for being so old, yet being so solid. Why games aren't being made like this anymore, who knows..

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												FIRST OFF, IF YOU ARE CRASHING AFTER CHARACTER CREATION ON WINDOWS 10, DISABLE FRAME BUFFER AND SOFT SHADOW. YOU'RE WELCOME.TL;DR: Knights of The Old Republic is a classic RPG and an essential purchase for Star Wars or RPG fans. If you are a casual gamer, or do not want to any reading, I would pass on this game. The textures may be outdated, but the gameplay and atmosphere stand strong. The depth of this game is incredible, and titles like these come MAYBE once a decade.So, I get why you make not like KOTOR.It's slow to start. You have to learn D&D terminology and do a little internet research to make a good build. It's turn-based and feels awkward at times. The narrative drags along at first, and since you don't begin as a sith-slaying god like Obi-Wan or Skywalker, you may want to quit out of boredom.But honestly, please give this game a few hours to see if you like it. Knights of The Old Republic is one of the best and most in-depth things about the Star Wars franchise, and definitely their best game next to Battlefront II and Republic Commando.You begin as a lowly republic soldier whose fate lines up with some heavy hitters in the galaxy. While KOTOR sort-of starts off like Morrowind, where you assist a character in saving the world, it is soon up to you to bring down the Sith armies and rival gangs, and to restore order to the galaxy.On your journey, you will have to make many black-and-white moral decisions that have little to no ambiguity, and pretty barebones consequences. I don't really mind this honestly: it's Star Wars, not exactly a franchise known for grey areas.You will also meet many well-rounded and relatable characters along the way: Carth Onasi is a hardened Republic soldier who's seen more than his fair share of combat, and holds deep inner turmoil for what happened in his past. He tries to keep on the mission at hand, and is a strong leader despite his occasional cynicism.Mission Vao and Zaalbar are two rebellious, street-smart characters who are on the run, and have to look out for each other to survive. Their bond reminds me of something out of a movie.And the list goes on. KOTOR's allies that you discover on your journey to the light or dark side are ultimately what make this game so much fun. You may often see your allies talk amongst themselves, and occasionally even fight over small issues. This creates a sort of humanity and real vibe to the world you are playing in.KOTOR also divulges topics like religion, politics, racism, and more, often directly in the dialogue, or in situations with NPCs in the world. I've had to save racially oppressed aliens more than a few times from the punk♥♥♥♥♥humans. The Empire, while not an official superpower yet, holds control over the planets they conquer in a fascist, do-as-we-say kind of government. This was very interesting to see, as similar imagery directly alludes to Nazi Germany in The Force Awakens.The items and environments in KOTOR are fantastic and do the franchise great justice. Nothing I saw in-game took me out of the experience in any way, and the pace felt fine as I played.There are also many things to do apart from the "main story": you can help merchants, save or kill civilians, break into apartment rooms, go after bounty hunters or do bounties yourself, participate in duels, gamble, race swoop bikes, and the list goes on and on. While KOTOR sticks to the basic premise of jedi=good, sith=evil, there is enough creativity in the story for you to be the character you want to be. The story is not a one-note, drab playthrough; there are many different ways to play. The characters feel human enough that there is often moral conflict when in different situations.Honestly, I haven't even finished the game and I could write forever. KOTOR belongs up there with the likes of Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Deus Ex, and System Shock 2 for the best RPGs of all time. Get this if you like Star Wars or RPGs.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												The gameplay feels out of date by today's standards, but it's very similar to a turn based rpg.  Skill points are scarce enough to make you feel like you're making real choices upon level up (a common feature of older rpgs).  I found the game to be challenging, but easy mode should let you get through if you just want to experience the story.  The story is incredible and that's what makes this game a must play.   It took me a little bit to get into the game, but I eventually got hooked.   There's multiple endings so playing the game through twice just to get very different endings is worth it.  This game is worth the standard price, but if you ever see it on sale PICK IT UP!

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Star Wars KOTOR is an RPG made by the RPG masters at Bioware. As a fan of Star Wars myself, I was excited to finally play this game. I've heard really good things about this game and I was not let down by this game.Pros:+The Story.... MY GOSH THE STORY (I won't spoil a thing because its that good)+The morale system that greatly affects the story, characters, atmosphere, and ending.+The characters feel three dimensional with their extensive backstories and colorful personalities.+The background lore to this game is really well done and when you look at it closley you'll see the parallels to the movies+The design of the locations is top-notch+Gives a more in-depth look at the Star Wars universe.Cons:-Graphics look a little dated, but not too bad.-The Real Time combat got boring to me after a while (although this is something that I don't like in RPGs in general)-It had to endOverall, (9/10) This game is a masterpiece and it is a must-buy to all Star Wars fans.P.S. To me this game is canon, I'm looking at YOU DISNEY!!!!!!

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												The graphics aren't amazing, and there are a lot of glitches (save often), but the storyline is interesting. The characters can come across as a little flat, because interaction is left mainly to between-mission interaction, and the skill system is a little awkward but by the end, I felt like I'd actually become a jedi, which is pretty freaking cool.  Over all, the game has aged surprisingly well. Side note: if you have a hard time getting the game to run at first, go to the steam folder where the game was installed run swconfig.exe, check turn off movies, and uncheck enable hardware mouse if it's enabled. If you can't find the steam folder, right click the game, click properties, and under the third tab select 'browse local files'.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Great game. However, this port, or at the very least this version of this port crashes constently in Windows 10. This is a problem which I have verified occurs frequently among Windows 10 users. This problem is NOT present in KOTOR II, strangely enough, and is unique to this game. Some methods which partially fix the problem do exist, but I would advise against purchasing this game if you have Windows 10, unless an update is released addressing these problems.***Edit from 12/28/2016***Even after running fixes of the game to make it more playable, it is marred by multiple graphical bugs, including one which makes character models partially invisible in wildnerless combat zones such as the fields of Dantooine and Taris's Undercity. These bugs do not outright make the game unplayable, but they do ruin cutscenes and make targeting enemies more awkward, alomng with ruining any sort of immersion.***Edit from 1/23/2016***A bunch of people are commenting that they have Windows 10 and are not having the same difficulties, stating that I must have done something wrong. I thought might have been my fault as well, initially, but I checked the Steam Forums and elsewhere and have found that there are frequent issues with running this game on Windows 10.I do think that this is a good game and recommend it to those not using Windows 10. If you do use Windows 10, I advise caution. If it works for you, then that's great, but there are clearly problems here. These problems are NOT present in KOTOR II, with I was able to run at length without issue.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												STAR WARS - Knights of the Old Republic is a truly beautiful adventure that can only be truly understood through playing. The game will always hold the number one position in my heart.In terms of storytelling, the game is unparalled. It features a diverse range of interesting and loveable characters who all undergo major character development, and will ellicit some form of emotion from you, be it laughter, sadness or anything in between.The storyline itself is easily the greatest amongst star wars games, and easily compares to other powerhouses of it's genre. The branching story lines empower the player, making you feel like every single dialogue option, or path of action can, and will have lasting repurcussions. Not falling into any clichés or overused plot devices, the storyline is an emotionally fuelled, gripping adventure that will have you staying up until 2 o'clock every morning, just to see how a particular event pans out.The graphics, though somewhat dated, detract 0 from the experience, and are quickly forgotten amongst the rich and vibrant worlds, teeming with interesting side characters and side missions, begging to be explored. Although linear, the worlds feel open and diverse, augmented by anyones previous knowledge of star wars.Many people preach the replayability, and I could not agree more; But certain aspects can only experienced once, and if I could erase my own memory to experience these things again, I would do so without a second thought. The game has mind blowing scenes, scenes that I wouldn't dare spoil so that everyone could experience the same as I did.All in All, I could not reccommend this game to any higher degree. I cannot fault it. It will leave you constantly wanting more. It is in my opinion, the perfect game.

												For those having problems with loading the first part of the game: Go to Options, advanced options, go to graphics, go to advanced, and disable Frame Buffer Effects.Now to the review.Pros:+Good character voice acting+Pretty decent graphics for it's time+Jeremy Soule (Music composer for this game) who also did the work on Skyrim did a marvelous job+Great atmosphere. Everything is very well designed and well-placed.+Fantastic Story+Great game length (about 40 hours)+Very Replayable+Good combat+Great main Villian+Amazing and lovable characters+Pretty fun sidequestsCons:-Starts off a little slow. But in my experience, most fantastic games do.-Money is a ♥♥♥♥♥ to come by in the early stages of the game.-After you beat the game, you cannot continue. SO DO ALL SIDEQUESTS IF YOU EVEN CONSIDER DOING THEM-Takes over your life-Puzzles are often complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Luckily, there aren't many of them.If you like Star Wars, get this game. if you like kickass stories, get this game. This is a classic and a must-play. Enjoy! :)

Posted: February 9, 2016
												Star Wars: tKotOR  is one of the greatest rpgs ever made. It is a truly magical delve into the Star Wars universe, with an expansive story, interesting characters, and challenging turn-based gameplay. The game has some of the best roleplay elements extantt o date and allows for the player to go far above and beyond the typical black/white morality of many morality-driven  rpgs. That all being said, the Steam version does not work. A quick google search will show you just how broken and unplayable this version of the game is. There has been no attempt to update this game for modern computers and even in compatability mode, it does not function. There are literally thousands of game-breaking bugs and glitches in the steam version that make it unplayable.Please, please, play this game but for the love of god, save yourself the frustration and do not buy the Steam version. Wait for a sale on GOG. Steam couldn't care less about how this game does not work.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												One of my favourite games of all time and the greatest Star Wars game ever released. I probably will get downvotes for this, but when I bought this game at launch, I had never actually seen the Star Wars movies (I spend more time gaming, instead of movies), so I only knew the basics. This game (+Star Wars Galaxies) made me like the Star Wars franchise and watch the movies. You could compare Star Wars Knights Of The Old Republic to Mass Effect, also made by Bioware. What makes SW:KOTOR such a great game to me is without a doubt the story. The choices you (have to) make, good vs bad, light side vs dark side and one of the best endings I've ever seen in any game. Most of the npc's are interesting and you build relationships with them, as the story progresses.Obviously, the graphics have aged over the years but It still manages to make the Star Wars universe feel alive. For example, there are space ships flying around, even though they only consist of a few pixels, you still know what they are and makes the world feel more alive. Combat is semi turn-based and often relies on tactical thinking. You are able to play KOTOR in real-time but you will probably die often.Like I said before; Star Wars Knights Of The Old Republic, mainly relies on the story. Unless you are a real Star Wars fan, this game is not recommended for players who rather have great combat but for anyone else this game is one everyone should have played, before they are dead.

content:
Posted: February 8
												KOTOR is truly a great rpg. The game immerses the player in the Star Wars universe, and It has some of the best voice acting and stories that I have heard in an RPG to date (and this is 2010). There's actually a focused and captivating story unlike most rpgs in the market today. I didn't really find any problems with the interface or gameplay (for its time). I really enjoyed Candorous' stories of the Mandalorian Wars, for example. They were compact with imagery and none of the dialogue seems superfluous. I seriously don't understand why this game should get anything less than a 9. I have played nearly every Star Wars game to date (and certainly many rpgs) and KOTOR is definitely one that sets the standards high. Don't be fooled by the low reviews. If you're a fan of rpgs, this is a must have.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												When I look back on KOTOR now, I think classic Bioware mechanics, classic Star Wars story. The merging of two formulaic entities to create something that is certainly standard fair for Bioware nowadays and probably hammered to death in the Star Wars universe. That said, I think about the experience when this game actually came out and it's hard to deny that there is something special that happened here. From a plot and story perspective; A true Ode to Star Wars that encapsulates the feeling of the first movies (4,5 and 6) so truly that it's hard to fault them on the story being so familiar. If you've played Bioware games since, you will also be familiar with what's going on under the hood as it plays very similar to other Bioware RPG's (Jade Empire, Dragon Age, etc) but again when this beast first came out a lot of these features were new and still exciting and that would probably be considered a strength instead of an overused format.    All other things aside, this is a game created by Bioware when it was in my opinion, at it's best and what Bioware did best was write engaging stories with characters that were filled with genuine humanity. So even though the format might seem tired now, the story and the characters are truly one of a kind and if you're playing through for the first time I would bet that some of your favorite moments you experience in this game would likely become some of your fondest memories that you have in the Star Wars universe as a whole.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Kotor was my first BioWare title and still my favorite. The graphics are a bit dated, however, and the combat takes a lot of getting used to if you're a first timer (turn based d20 system ala DnD) but once you get used to it you'll be hooked. This game is somewhat notorious for having a slow start (Taris/Dantooine) and not all planets are action-y (Manaan) but when it's good it's really good. The story is captivating and open, giving you choices on how you want to take on the plot, which has a crazy twist. The characters are fleshed out and the writing and voice acting are well done too. Everyone will find something to like in this game. I was lucky to find it on sale, however, it's still worth the full price point at $9.99. Hands down the best Star Wars experience along with Battlefront 1 and 2. Go get this game.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												I'm aware I don't have many hours logged on this game for the PC. However, as kid I played this on the original Xbox back in the day. So trust me on this.1.) This game is by far my favorite in the Star Wars series, it's unique RPG style was unlike any game at the time (at least for me.) The choices you made in-game defined your character from the Jedi, Sith or even the interesting/unique Grey jedi and each choice could impact in small/ large ways the overall outcome of the story and your companions which makes for a lot of replay value.2.) The story (without spoilers of course) is very compelling and complex with many new challeneges as you progress further and even a few twists and turns that keep the story exciting and not dragged out. The characters are interesting and fun to learn more about once you start forming bonds with them through your adventures.3.) Turn based combat which is interesting and though wasn't my favorite style of combat, the formula for this game just feels right and flows well for what it is. It makes weapon modifications, skills and talents, armor and modifications and even the choice of companions important based on the enemies you may face in each and every encounter.4.) Just buy this game! it's worth it. If you like a game where you create your own path, then make one in this beautiful universe of Knights of the Old Republic. Years have aged this game but it's a hidden gem you can't find anywhere else.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												I'm a huge Star Wars fan, so keep that in mind as you read this review.I just played this game for the first time a couple weeks ago, and it was one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had in terms of gaming in a while. Despite this game being 13 years old it is much better than many games that have come out recently.My favorite thing about Bioware games, whether it be Mass Effect, Dragon Age, or Knights of the Old Republic, is the characters that Bioware creates. I fell in love with every single character in this game. The interactions you can have with each character after every mission is great and something I always looked forward to while playing. I thought the romance with Bastila was well written and actually believable, unlike many other games. Also, as a huge fan of the Mass Effect series, it was so cool recognizing voice actors in this game, and they did a great job.The plot in this game is well done in my opinion. I obviously won't go into specifics as I don't want to spoil anything, but the foreshadowing is great, and the plot twist is awesome. Freaking lightsabers. The one thing I was looking forward to most coming into this game was crafting my first lightsaber, it wasn't all that great, but still pretty cool. Other than that, lightsabers are probably the coolest thing ever imagined and just being able to use one instantly makes this game awesome.The combat in this game was something I was not used to and still don't like very much. I was coming into this game expecting to run around swinging my lightsaber randomly at enemies like you would in skyrim. However, this game has MMO type combat where you just click on enemies and the game takes care of the rest. I hated this at first but after a while I was ok with it.Overall, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a fantastic game, and my new most favorite. There are so many things done right in this video game. If you're a fan of Star Wars buy this game you will love it. If you're not a fan of Star Wars I still definitely recommend this game as it's one of the greatest of all time. I rate this game a 10/10.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												There are countless positive reviews on how this is one of the most brilliant RPG's ever made so I am just going to touch on a few things and lend a few quick pointers to people who are brand new to Kotor. The first thing to note is that the game is quite buggy, crashes occur at random and minimizing will periodically result in a crash as well. There are not enough auto saves in the game so SAVE OFTEN. This will prevent some serious frustration. The second thing to note is that the start of the game can be difficult to sink your teeth into. You may find your interest is not aroused immediately, just remember to give it time. I had to put the game down several times at the beginning as my interest waned. Come back with a fresh mind and push through and you will soon find the game much more immersive and rewarding after you contend with the beginning. Knights of the Old Republic is the Baldur's Gate of Star Wars games and is one of the greatest RPG's ever made. A no brainer for RPG enthusiasts and Star Wars fans.

He became so powerful... the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												There are very few games out there that I would declare 10/10 games, this is one of them. Ever since the original Star Wars trilogy ended 30 years ago we have been given lackluster successors to the trilogy in both film and video game. Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a game that really captures the narrative sense of adventure and good vs evil that made the original three films such joys to watch. (SPOILERS AHEAD) The characters you interact with are for the most part a very strong point of the game. Carth is a tortured character you really to have to spend a lot of time to understand. Bastilia is a gifted Jedi who is attempting to be the emotionless patient Vulcan-like Jedi we have come to known in the prequel films which makes it all the more fun to really get her angry at you. Mission Vao and Zaalbar are basically Chewbacca and Han solo if Han was a 13 year old girl. Jolee Bindo is one of the more interesting Jedi you’ll ever encounter; he’s not a member of the Jedi order and dodges any attempts you make to probe his character. Canderous Ordo is a perfect specimen of a Mandalorian (the human version of Predators) and is a combat veteran. You get two droids on your adventures, T3 who is basically R2-D2 and my favorite companion HK-47, a assassin droid who refers to all non droids as “Meatbags” and who you’ll learn is responsible for the deaths of all his previous masters. Oh and if you run into someone called “Juhani” just kill her, it saves you a lot of time. The Combat of this game is turn-based and as you gain more levels you are able to spec into a variety of different abilities which will give you new options when it comes to fighting enemies. However the calling card of this game is the story (MAJOR, GAME RUINING SPOILERS AHEAD). The game leads you to believe at first you are a Republic (insert class here) stationed on a ship orbiting Taris and it is up to save the galaxy by rescuing the Jedi leader of the ship’s expedition who was lost on the planet following an attack by the main enemy of the game Dark Malak. You then learn after you escape the planet you learn that you are gifted and can learn the powers of the Force. You take this as simply coincidence and continue on your journey to stop Malak (M. NIGHT SHAMALYAN SPOILERS AHEAD, LAST CHANCE TO TURN BACK). However in one of the greatest plot twists in video games, you learn that your character is actually “Darth Revan” the former master of Malak whose memory was changed by the Jedi Council. Now while this game is my favorite of my all time favorites it does have its faults. There are extra quests in the game that are just not do able unless you so happen to do planets in exact orders, the first two planets (Taris and Dantooine) are major drags to get through and are not the most enjoyable things to get through. Despite this, Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is the greatest Star Wars game to exist and is easily worth the 10 dollars.If the droid in Rogue One is a HK-47 Clone i'm going to be annoyed.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a team-based third person RPG set in the distant past of the Republic in the Star Wars universe. It is an excellent game, and a great RPG in the vein of other Bioware RPGs. Mechanically, it is a little dated and can take some getting used to, and the early portions of the game can drag a little bit, but once you get to the meat of the game, it's one of the best RPGs of all time, and a truly, truly excellent game.It's been some time since I played through it, so I'm afraid the details have faded, but it's really a must-play for fans of the genre or of Star Wars. It's one of the best Star Wars properties which has ever been made, and it's a great game that stands up even a decade later.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, also know as "KOTOR" to fans of the series, is one of the true founding fathers of the RPG genre. This game, which produced a metascore rating of 93 out of 100, takes you into the Star Wars universe, and lets you "run free." You can choose the path you which to take, whether it be the light side or the dark side, and you can decide which planets you wish to visit. Along the way you will encounter new characters and aliens, some of whom will even join your party. KOTOR is a game for those who enjoy long, deep stories that let you truly decide who your character becomes. It has an incredible soundtrack created by Jeremy Soule, who later went on to compose the soundtrack for multiple games, including Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim of the Elder Scrolls series, and the Harry Potter video game series. If you're looking for a first person shooter or a game with intense combat, this game is not for you. The combat is primarily turn based, and can take some getting use to. However, if you are looking for an RPG that you can immerse yourself in and play for the story, then Knights of the Old Republic is the RPG for you.

Every decision you make counts so its up to you to decide whether to save or destroy the universe. Will you join the Dark Side and make them feel the power of the Sith or will you wage an impossible effort to save the galaxy while remaining true to the teachings of the Jedi?W/e u choose may the Force be with you!!!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Before I start this review I'd like to say that this isn't the first time I have played this game as I played it a while back on the original Xbox and I just had to buy it again for PC because 1. The PC graphics are slightly better 2. The mods you can download are AMAZING and 3. I just had to.. its star wars okay I just had to, So lets get started with this review and firstly lets talk about the gameplay.Gameplay: At first it took me sometime to get used to playing this on PC with the mouse and keyboard but I adapted quickly to it and to be perfectly honest I prefer playing it this way than on the Xbox simply because it is sooo much easier to click on which enemy you want to attack rather than scrolling through each enemy with a gaming controller and also navagating the menu's on PC is highly superior and its pretty obvious why. The combat in this game is fun most of the time as you would issue a command and your characters will carry out that command without you having to mash buttons or whatever kind of like a Final Fantasy game but in more of a real time than that, but at times it can be very repetitive and enemies can just get annoying as it feels like they are stopping you from carrying out the story but this is just a minor grip with the gameplay as most of the time I felt very happy with the combat its just certain areas in the game the enemies get a little tendious (Damn Khath Hounds.) Story: Well this is definetly the strongest part of the game as it is a Bioware game (Known for  the Mass effect series, Dragon Age and Jade Empire) and when you buy a Bioware game you know the story is going to be good and in this case the story is DAMN GOOD. I won't give anything away story wise but something happens later on that made my jaw drop. Overall story wise this game has a ton of sub plots as well such as the characters you interact with that come along with you on this journey all have their own back stories that mostly impact the main plot in some way and are also very interesting (well mostly).Graphics: The graphics of this game are very good for its time and I think they still hold up today I mean it is a dated game so its not going to look amazing but with some extra mods you can download the game looks even better and theres nothing bad I can really say about this.Overall verdict: Well I would say if you enjoy games that are heavily focused on story and if you love Star Wars (who doesn't) this is a must buy.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
Star Wars | Knights of the Old Republic is an Adventure RPG based on the D20 System. Set 4,000 years before the Galactic Empire, you are a Republic Soldier stuck in a war against a newly formed Sith Empire lead by former Jedi heroes, whose steps you retrace in an attempt to discover the source of their military power.Pros: Nice story that explores the ages before the modern Star Wars setting, back when the Republic was half its size and most of the Galaxy was yet to be mapped. You are joined by a cast of up to 8 additional characters, up to 2 can join you at a time. You can travel to 5 different planets (with different environments, creatures to fight, and equipment to buy for you and your party). Different encounters or quests might unlock depending on which side character is in your party at a given time. Some items are upgradable standard enhancement parts, others are fully customizable such as lightsabers. Multiple side quests allow you to delve on which side of the force you want to be in. Oh, and the story has a great twist!Cons: The graphics didn’t age too well, many objects and characters look very polygony. If you’re not familiar with tabletop RPGs and the D20 system, you can easily get confused of how the mechanics work when selecting weapons, upgrades and other equipment. Character creation is limited, at least by today’s standard, where you pick from a dozen pre-gen faces among 3 different classes to begin, then among 3 jedi classes. Each planet has a very linear map, with a few outbranching paths, again contrasting with today’s standards.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your listIf you’re not a fan of Star Wars, you probably won’t see the appeal of this game. Otherwise, it’s one of the best installments of the games. The game isn’t too lore-heavy, allows both light and hardcore fans to enjoy the settings and game. I recommend giving it a try, it’s worth the price!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2013
												his WRPG brought to you by Bioware was a stunning release for its time and playing it really shows you where their newer games have come from. But how does it stand up to some of the standards set by their newer RPGs? Pretty well, in fact; however, there were some pretty major annoyances and some issues I did have with the game. For starters, I just got done playing Planescape: Torment, and that WRPG (released 4 years earlier) had infinitely better decision making paths than KotOR did. I recognize that this *may* be due to the confines of working in the Star Wars universe: you have the Dark Side and the Light Side - each contrary to the other, but really I felt it could have been done better. Your options in KotOR seem to boil down to A) I'm going to help you out or B) I'm going to be a huge ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Example: You are in the slums and you have the ability to save a race of people for light side points. The dark side path is you can sell them out to some junk dealer because he wants to keep his profits up *for a measly 100 credits*! Just to let you know, that's not a lot of credits. And if you don't pick a side and want to stick in the middle path then guess what, no awesome light/dark side affiliated equipment for you sir! Speaking of roleplaying, if you decide you want to roleplay as a blaster user then you're going to have a bad time. As I said, I just got done with Planescape and I figured, "why not go a charasmatic path" like I did in that game. Well, KotOR thinks it's fun to throw you into 1v1 duels quite frequently, and if you don't have a lightsabre or focus on combat you're going to have some serious aggravation. Eventually I got through them and carved a niche for myself by spamming the Insanity and Force Wave abilities. Those abilities got me all the way through the final boss of the game, so another complaint I would have is game balancing - whether it's combat, dialogue choices to avoid battle, or other ways to accomplish things, I think this game could use a once-over. Some of the characters were also a little one-sided, not just regarding light vs dark side, but wholly uninteresting. Take T3-M4 for instance. Yes, it's a droid, but R2-D2 had a personality and T3-M4 doesn't, which is disappointing and I can only attribute it to laziness. The game is also a little glitchy. My characters ended up getting caught in doorways quite often and during conversational cutscenes sometimes weird things would happen - eg holding invisible weapons. A few final annoyances were whenever you suit up (either underwater or in outerspace) you walk stupidly slow and every time you travel from planet to planet the cutscenes are recycled and you end up playing the same repetitive "space battle" minigame. KotOR also has bad and unfrequent quicksave times (spam that F4 key!). The inventory was also quite a mess, a lot of wasted screen real estate in the menus and it was nigh impossible to determine exactly what items you receive as quest rewards.While the above may seem like a long list it really didn't effect my enjoyment *too* much (except for those 1v1 duels, ugh) and the game has a lot of merit to it. There are many fun and challenging puzzles, the music is phenomenal, using motiffs we know and recognize from Star Wars that weave seamlessly in and out of original material that keeps the nostalgia flowing, and the controls are quite good, allowing you to mostly play with your mouse hand only. And, most importantly, the story was excellent. I was really impressed overall with the narrative and felt empathy for most of the characters in my party (I really loved the other droid you get as well, meatbags!). Pros:NarrativeCharacterizationMusicLots of character customizationCons:Lack of "good" character customization from protagonistA little too "black and white"Some annoyances (see above)All in all it was a memorable journey that I would recommend you try if you like Star Wars or Bioware/WRPGs but it falls short of my "must play" stamp of approval. B+

												In this classic game by Bioware you play as Dash Rendar, a sassy, no-nonsense mercenary and smuggler. The goal of this game is to go around and try to become a Pokemon Pazaak master. However, most of the time you are aimlessly drifting around alien worlds, and solving other people's meaningless problems. But I know why many of you are reading this, and so I'll cut to the most important bit of information, you don't get a lightsaber until 5 hours into the game. A silly oversight by Bioware Corp, but what's even sillier is the fact they completely forgot this important piece of equipment in this game's sequel, Mass Effect! You know why Shepard ultimately failed in that series? Because he didn't have a damn lightsaber. There, I said it.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												The story is good. There is a nice twist and it gives you some clues along the way. I can't say too much more without spoiling it.The gameplay is very similar to other games like Baldur's Gate, but at a closer third person view and with a smaller party. Don't expect an open world, as areas are very small and closed off. In the late game you will find yourself wanting to stack your party with jedi with the heal and flurry abilities. Since you have little-to-no control over whether you hit, how you hit, or how you get hit, bosses end up being punching bags. They ignore your control abilities with saving throws and your heals can typically out-heal any damage they deal out. Your lightsabers also protect you well from blasters and other melee enemies die very quickly.Characters are good. I thought I could romance a twi'lek who turned out to be 14. One is a conspiracy nut and a certain old man likes to use jedi mind tricks. For once, I actually liked getting involved with characters and knowing their backstory, whereas I am usually interested in the backstory of the world. This game is a steal for $10. Graphics don't matter in this game. Gameplay holds up, but try to avoid min-maxing to avoid makign the game too easy. Try to roleplay a little with your party coomposition. Buy this game for the story and the characters. 8/10.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												In all my 20 years of living. I have played everything from Super Mario RPG, all the way up to FarCry 4 and Fallout New Vegas, no game gives me a feeling, no, a sensation of feeling like a total badass like Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. bonus points given due to it being made by Bioware.Basic storyline: This game is set some 4,000 years before the original trilogy, during this time, the Sith are trying to take over the entire galaxy, just like your average bad guy corporation, after you spend thirty or so minutes of game time aboard a ship that should've been destroyed by the time you first opened your eyes, you already will have the basic controls down. After a few hours, you will get the force, despite this. I still tended to stick with the tried and true rifle-type weapons, even though the lightsabers, which come in dual, short and standard types, are incredible to look at and use,   RPG Elements: The greatest asset in this game, to me, is the ability to modify certain weapons and armour, including lightsabers and Jedi Robes that turn you into a walking laser sponge, the addition of a conversation system was one of the first examples I've seen, and was used later just as innovatively in the Mass Effect series. Final thoughts: I love this game, it's light-hearted, but can be serious at the same time. I never had as much love for the second KoTOR game, because it didn't feel like the same game, if you're either a veteran of RPG's or are a kid just starting their journey into the gaming world, this is one of my personal top picks, it's fun, it can run on a potato, and for the hardcore Star Wars fan, it holds a little surprise from the comic series.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2012
												Bioware takes hold of George Lucas's Star Wars universe and expands it with engrossing story in Knights of the Old Republic (KotOR). Played from a third-person perspective, KotOR is a fun and thrilling role-playing game that caters to Star Wars nerds and appeases the fans of the Expanded Universe. Although dated, KotOR is a must for fans of the Star Wars series as well as Bioware die-hards. If you can look beyond the technical limitations on modern systems and accept a change of pace from traditional first-person shooters, KotoR will keep you entertained at a cheap price.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												In this classic game by Bioware you play as Dash Rendar, a sassy, no-nonsense mercenary and smuggler. The goal of this game is to go around and try to become a Pokemon Pazaak master. However, most of the time you are aimlessly drifting around alien worlds, and solving other people's meaningless problems. But I know why many of you are reading this, and so I'll cut to the most important bit of information, you don't get a lightsaber until 5 hours into the game. A silly oversight by Bioware Corp, but what's even sillier is the fact they completely forgot this important piece of equipment in this game's sequel, Mass Effect! You know why Shepard ultimately failed in that series? Because he didn't have a damn lightsaber. There, I said it.

The mechanics are old, but work flawlessly, the story is incredibly modular, and at that, it's great, the characters are unique and interesting, and who wouldn't want to be a damn Sith Lord?Essentially you and two others are the sole survivors of a ship that is attacked by the Sith. From their the story escalates and soon your a Jedi Knight with the decision of whether to follow the path of the dark side or to stay on the light. Your choices impact the outcome of the game.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												There is the reason why this game considered one of the best RPGs of all time. Made by Bioware long before they started soap opera by the name of Mass Effect, Star Wars: KotOR offers everything that PC Western RPG supposed to - non-linear structure, choices that affects game world, great, engaging story, and memorable characters. I am sure that I did not see everything this game has to offer, like ways of the Sith, or evens that will happen if you visit planets in different order. Some things not aged that well, like lack of fast travel system between cleared of enemies’ areas or somewhat clunky interface. Made in 2003, KotOR does not support widescreen resolutions; however, this can be fixed with Flawless Widescreen.Just buy this game and play it, it does not matter if you watched any of the Star Wars movies hence game takes place 4000 years before any of the movies.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												Bwee. This game might be old now, but its still one of the best RPG's ever made. Star Wars might be a tainted franchise in alot of ways, having produced alot of garbage and many terrible games. But some is good... and some is great, and this is one of the great things.Gameplay wise, it came between Baldur's Gate and Mass Effect, and you can see traces of both games in this one (the "dice" combat from BG and the dual morality and third person gameplay of ME). A few parts of the game are a bit slow, most of all in the beginning, but the later areas more than make up for this. And story... well, you will have to see that for yourself. No spoilers from me! It's one of the best in any RPG, with plenty of interesting characters to go with it. Especially that... droid. You will know which one when you meet them.This game pretty much always gets hugely discounted during major sales, so if you don't have this one you may as well pick it up cheap and check it out. You may find something you will like here. :)

content:
Posted: April 15
												This is the greatest game BioWare has ever produced. Perhaps even the greatest game of all time. The plot is beautiful (and full of at least one big surprise). The characters are wonderful. And the world(s) are expansive. Set 3960 years before the Battle of Yavin IV (end of Episode IV), this game deals with the Jedi Civil War, the conflict that started after the great Jedi heroes Revan and Malak chased rumors of dark forces behind the Mandalorian Wars they had just won for the Republic. A year later, they returned... changed... and at the head of a force of fallen Jedi and Sith.Now Revan is missing, thought killed by Malak in an act of betrayal. And Darth Malak's forces are now hunting the last Jedi to extinction. And proving that Darth Revan's reign was quite nice compared to his...You are a new warrior. Soldier, scout, or scoundrel you are aboard the ship Endar Spire over Taris when Malak attacks. You escape and now need to track down the missing Bastila Shan, a Jedi Knight with a great power. Soon, you will discover your place in galactic events. And change history for the better... or the worse.This game is the first glimpse of Revan, the larger-than-life Jedi Master and Sith Lord. One who had a great impact on Galactic History. And as part of the distant past... still possibly a part of the history in the new canon. It also is the first time you meet HK-47, one of the most iconic droids in Star Wars lore. Also one of the funniest, considering it is an assassin droid.One note: Juhani, one of the companions in-game is likely the earliest BioWare character that has an... interest in their own gender.Cannot recommend this game enough.My gameplay time does not reflect my time in-game, as off-line play is not counted.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												10 years ago this game was released to critical acclaim, winning multiple GOTY awards for obvious reasons to those that have played it. If you havent played it yet I strongly recommend you do as it is essentially your own Star wars trilogy. Ill go into why it is so in a spoiler section at the end but this game has such a great twist I wouldnt advise reading into it. But enough exposition and acclaim, The game feels like Star wars; From the fantastic sound design that captures the original score perfectly to the sound of lightsabers clashing and blasters firing. The set-peices, ships, weapons and armor all look like they are of some older era of the star wars universe capturing that feeling of an even longer time ago. The story and subject matter is (arguably) the best ever told and/or touched on in the Star wars universe telling countless stories of redemption, betrayal, revenge, hope, loss, sacrafice,ascension,downfall the list goes on, you become the embodiment of the character you play (good or evil) be it Sith, Jedi, Bounty hunter, Soldier, Scoundrel with any number intertwining for you to create this story thats set a long a fixed path into something of your own. Again making it your very own Star wars trilogy....************************************SPOILERS************************************************************************************From the point it begins to the point you escape Taris and arrive at the Jedi temple on Dantooine I consider to be the First Episode in th KOTOR trilogy and a story of the players new beginning (obviously). From the time you begin your training at the Jedi temple to the confronation and big reveal to be Episode II and the defining of the characters ascenion be it Dark or light. Events that Follow being Episode III with culmination of the Characters final acts as a savior and a Jedi or a Dark Lord of the sith.... Truly epic.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Where do you begin, when they ask you to review one of the best games of all time? It's hard, I tell you what. But I'll give it a shot, regardless.My first experience with Knights of The Old Republic was on the original xbox, back in the year of 2004. And my only memories from it are good ones, walking on the bottom of the sea on the ocean world of Manaan, or wandering around amongst the trees of the wookie planet of Kashyyyk all made you feel incredible due to the great sound-design and beautiful (at the time) visuals. The gameplay can feel a bit slow and sluggish by todays standards since it's not superfast and pulse pounding the way some games are, but that's not what it was about, and frankly, I rarely cared so much about the gameplay in this title because of the fact that the story, the characters and the setting is what brings this puppy home. It's safe to say that what Bioware created with this title was a game of the ages, something that would stand the test of time forever, and proudly so. When people place this game on their "Best games of all times" list, they do not do it for any other reason than the one that it is a god damn good game.The story will take you far and wide, beginning with your character (which you can customize, male-female, caucasian/hispanic/african etc) waking up on board of a republic ship that is under attack by Sith forces, for you who don't know, the sith are the "bad" guys. In the spirit of spoiling as little as possible, you end up on a city-planet called Taris, where you have to take on an underground crime syndicate, join a swoop race (kind of like floating motorcycles) and take out a crimeboss. All while doing this, you will meet companions who joins your party. The companions are varied, and extremely well fleshed out, and they all have good voice-actors (admittedly some better than others).By the time you're done on the world of Taris, you will have spent about 3-6 hours in the game, depending on how much time you spent doing sidequests, exploring and talking to your companions. And that's just the first "major world" that you get to visit during your main quest, which I shall not spoil for you! Regardless, you have several more worlds to visit during your quest, and the game can take you anywhere from hardly any time, to a god damn lifetime to complete. All in all, I rate this game a perfect score, there is a bug here and there, but they are rare and have never (to me) been gamebreaking. So to summarize:Amazing storyAmazing charactersAmazing setting and locationsAmazing gameplay (in my opinion, this is more subjective since some do not like the DnD combat in RPGs)Amazing sound-design and soundtrack (composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule!)It's a god damn 10 out of 10 in my book. And everyone should at least give this game a try. :)

content:
Posted: August 8, 2013
												It's hard to find games like this. Its complexity. Its story. Its intrigue. Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic draws out as an instant role-playing game classic, influenced modern RPGs like never before. Developed by an unknown company, known as BioWare, the game is a golden hit by its original dialogue, choices, companions, and character development. The game even expands the Star Wars universe that can equate to the six Star Wars films by its popularity. Despite that the game was released in 2003, there is no argument that the game has a direct impact in popular culture and how it shapes other games, even Bethesda Studio's Elder Scrolls and Fallout series. Knights of the Old Republic is need to be played from anyone who thinks that other RPGs is better suit than this; they're wrong. Never underestimate the aged graphics and look upon its gameplay elements and choice elements that will determine your fate for the Star Wars galaxy.

												This game is one of my favorites of all time, and with Steam it does have some unexplained issues. If you're having major graphical glitches (but don't understand why because your computer isn't a chump,) turn off shadows and grass. Along with that, set compatiblity mode to run with Windows XP Service Pack 3. You're find it after right-clicking KOTOR in your library and going to Properties at the bottom of the pop-up menu. I was enraged by not knowing this, but I hoped I helped someone out there! Thanks.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												This game... is one of the most stunning RPGs I have ever come across. Having played it for many many years, I have never lost the urge to create a new character and blast my way across the game. Each character you come across is complex, richly developed and voice acted masterfully. The combat (Turn based) is fun and addictive if you're into the strategy-type games. SW:KotOR  also includes the classic Star Wars music, which any nerd such as myself can appreciate. Through each crazy plot twist, you're left feeling like you were actually a part of the story. That you were one with your character as your chose which dialogue option best fits your personality. For all the positives in the game, there are some blaring issues that bring it down, the most frusterating being the ending. After you spend hours traveling the galaxy, you suddenly feel rushed as if the game is leaping entire plot lines. You're here, then suddenly here and then over there, leaving very little room to digest what you've experienced. And SW:KotOR just wraps up. The entire ending zone just feels rushed and unpolished. In fact the entire game was unpolished. For it's fantastic plot and characters (the major seller to me personally), the game included numerous frusterating bugs and glitches, sometimes even crashing the game completely... If you look past it's somewhat chaotic nature, you'll find that Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic well deserves it's metascore, and i recommend a playthrough to all RPG lovers.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2013
												It's hard to find games like this. Its complexity. Its story. Its intrigue. Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic draws out as an instant role-playing game classic, influenced modern RPGs like never before. Developed by an unknown company, known as BioWare, the game is a golden hit by its original dialogue, choices, companions, and character development. The game even expands the Star Wars universe that can equate to the six Star Wars films by its popularity. Despite that the game was released in 2003, there is no argument that the game has a direct impact in popular culture and how it shapes other games, even Bethesda Studio's Elder Scrolls and Fallout series. Knights of the Old Republic is need to be played from anyone who thinks that other RPGs is better suit than this; they're wrong. Never underestimate the aged graphics and look upon its gameplay elements and choice elements that will determine your fate for the Star Wars galaxy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												This game is the best Star Wars game out there, and no doubt one of the best games on PC.Before you buy this, take note that you need to turn off Shadows, grass, steam overlay and theatere before you can play, or you will experince constant crashes.Despite it's graphics, this game was fun and full completion isn't easy. It's got light and Dark side choices, anything you do will determine that. There's no quick path to the light side, or the dark side, you can't pick and choose easily. The sidequests are plentiful and and probably take twice the time it takes to complete the main story. There are major problems, that can sometimes ruin the game.On the Korriban level, one of the tombs will break your 2nd companinon, which really sucked, because it broke HK-47.Every shot and block is all on chance, so even if your blaster is at point blank range, you still can't shoot that scruffy nerf-herder.Autosave doesn't work too wellSith enemies have an absouletly OP life drain, not only stunning you but healing themselves.You can sometimes go back "home" when in combat. This makes it so much easier, but takes the fun away.AWFULLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLL STARFIGHTER MINI GAMES. Everytime you leave a unsafe planet, starfighters go after you. It sucks you can't save, and the fact that turning is slow and painful makes it horrible. There are 6 starfighter, and if they hit you 2 times each, you die.Whats the best thing?The fact that Companions are bantha fodder, and guerilla tactics are awesome. Relying on them is hardly needed.The AI, is actually not crappy. It's pretty decent. (They still block you though)Leveling up characters, allows you to choose skills and powers to upgradeIt's almost free worldCollecting everything is very rewarding. In the end I had 12 lightsabers or something crazy like that.The plot is absoluetly epic, it goes with the regular star wars stuff, You are a force-user, you save the galaxy because you are the chosen guy, and have a wall of plot armor. But, the twist is absoluetly.....wow....and you'll want to play again for the ending you missed (dark or light) and all the side quests you left untended.10/10-ign10/10-gamestop10/10-angryjoe10/10-pegi1610/10-SunpaiSilverAussieCatBUY THE GAME ALREADYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												This is my first playing a Bioware game ever and hearing the popularity of Bioware in recent years of its story and characters I had to check it out, and what better way they manage to create in their early works and my favorite franchise, Star wars!Story I will try sum it up as much possible without any major spoilers, the story is average good I’m sorry to say I can’t be wow by the plot which I will explain later in more details, but the main plot is interesting don’t get me wrong. The light vs. dark side I should say is cliché but there are some story telling that is pretty surprisingly interesting picking up half way through the game. 	I chose to be light side because I’m always am and got motivated to defeat Malak the antagonist of the game. There are some nice moments where you go “awe” and “what” and that’s good, it shows Bioware was starting to stable themselves as the “capital ship” of 3rd party company.However, their earliest isn’t much what I expected because the backstory of the old Republic never mention this ever and even talks about the origin of the war. Yes they do talk about the rise of the Sith but just a brief one, I was expected a prequel of the star wars movies about telling the origin of what happen about everything; the war, the rise of Sith, the origin of the Republic everything, but no not a whole lot and both side doesn’t show much color. The Sith are so generic with their “I’m a snob so that means everyone I look is a weakling” their motivation of doing this to so weak to me, yes they do what Sith do but what they are doing just doesn’t convince me to show sympathy to them or even see them differently. Is just “he’s bad and we’re good.” What about the republic surely they are some goody-two shoes? Well at first almost but no they can be somewhat corruptive and wrong of their morals too! And that’s what I want from it, the republic side showing its own “both side” but also want the Sith to show “their two faces as well” instead of all being rich snob Nazis. A final note on this yes they do some moments with the Sith on Korriban but not entirely enough to see them as “they are evil but I can see their side point why they do this horrid things.”Charactersthe NPC and partners are interesting as well especially I like that when you got the time you can talk to them and hear some back stories even if you bring one of them along in one certain planet, more dialogue options to choose and you will have a good backstory of the character. Malak I think is a cool villain especially the way he talks plus and robo-jaw that he has is really cool to look at.Now here comes the problems I have this game and two things are repetitive and cliché for the story aspect side. The NPC of any species just looks the same especially on the human side they have the same texture face model which doesn’t add a lot of emersion seing the same human character twice and even the voice, the alien sort of get a pass but their voice over just doesn't because they reuse the same alien language dialouge many times and it gets tired around the ears. Yes, I know that Bioware was at their first steps and you could say is budget problem by not hiring more actors and having to change face textures about everything that won’t affect too much on the rating scale, is just a nitpick problem where you try to discover a new world with new species (though in my case I already know the species) but they sound the same you wanted to see many new variation looks/voice as possible. Hopefully in the second game when the game got very popular it will have more.Choose your sideAlright now the big one and is, which side would you choose, well I should say, none of it matters! Well what I meant was it really doesn’t matter in “morality,” yes of course you still choose your light and dark ending but at endgame, for the rest of the game it really doesn’t matter if you are the lightest person in the world, you can still choose the dark path at the end of the game. So what gives? What is the objective of those light side dark side points? Is really for gameplay wise in armor and weapons, the force powers I made my main character have some dark powers even some of my light-side partners, which doesn’t really matter if you are good or not you can still equip dark powers or light powers if you are choosing your endings. Another thing about the moral points is just cosmetic option but only in the dark path when your character begins to change color. So now it sounds like it only effects gameplay and not story telling which blows badly right? Well at first yes, I thought it would be the biggest disappointment ever since no matter if you are the biggest jerk in this galaxy or the nicest one you can switch sides in matter of seconds. Well I should say not entirely in that center problem, because you can still have consequence when doing certain side quest and do evil things and in some planets some characters will pay you back hard, if you are prepare.No, I think the big point taker has to be your partners’ reaction to the player’s action. Yes they say “you did a wrong thing” but they never “punish” you for it or better yet leave you or stop you even though they are the once that help you do the main’s dirty deed. Most of your partners are from the light side and whatever you do will make them react but not upon action which is really shame. I expect during some quests or the main “dialogue” choice your friends will abandon you and you will be recruit with more dark players and the story switch to another quest, “conquest” I thought. You can be the biggest jerk without a reason to them and they won’t even leave your side no matter what you did, even by the next set of choice that you made “wrong” you can switch to being nice again and they will forget about your “dirty deeds.” I find it odd that after everything I do bad they won’t bat an eye of my behavior which just tells me that my choice won’t affect much around me until the very end, but during the whole game experience I thought choosing one side might affect the story telling as two sides, one fight for the good or join the Sith and fight from the republic and you will eventually fight Yoda! (Which I know that isn’t him.) My main when going dark or light doesn’t give a deeper meaning why he’s doing it, I’m just having that express feeling that “I do it because I’m a bully and want to take things just because,” “I’m good because I’m a goodie two-shoes,” and mind you I’m talking about story wise, the gameplay well that is different because I want the extra status boost.The side missions some I like but is just another generic “do this because is the right thing to do and do this because you are a jerk” Even the options you choose sounds a bit preachy for me thinking “well duh of course is bad to do this but should I?” There is only one side quest I think is my favorite where it involve no light or dark side points and only pure morality choice which about there I got a moral dilemma and I wish there was more like that but I know if it is it makes the system even more pointless.Verdict: The final verdict is a 7/10 a good starting game for Bioware’s time but need improvement on the writing, and moral choice but other than that I did enjoy the game despite some minor flaws the gameplay works flawlessly and I don’t have much of a problem to say, hopefully when I finish star war kotor 2 maybe things will change and improve until then, may the force be with you.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												If you ever wondered where games like Mass Effect or Dragon Age came from, then sit down, my child, and let me tell you of a game called KOTOR. This game is one of the best, all-time Western RPGs. Yeah, it's showing its age compared to more modern RPGs. Yeah, the combat system is clunky and easy to exploit (the AI's pathing is awful). Yeah, the graphics aren't the great thing they were back in the early 2000s. But the real heart of this game is the story and characters. It was one of the first games of its kind and wasn't afraid to take risks, paying homage to the old Star Wars trilogy while creating its own interesting universe and characters. I had this game as a kid on my old Dell (it was piece of junk) like ten years ago and I thought this game was the♥♥♥♥♥♥back then. Basically, you play as a Jedi trying to stop the Sith from destroying the Republic. You can use the Force to bring unholy destruction on the dirty non-Jedi plebes or even just use blasters, because lightsabers are for the weak.Generally, the choices go between being the nicest guy (or lady!) in the galaxy, or being a total♥♥♥♥♥♥ But there's a lot of good writing you don't see in a lot of modern video games. Especially from your companions (9 of them in total). I'm able to get it running on my MSI laptop w/Windows 10, so I'm not sure the difficulty others are having. I disabled movies and it works just fine (you're not missing out on anything essential with the movies). Also, get Flawless Widescreen from somewhere in the internets if you have a large monitor, it helps a bunch with some of the visual glitches users run into. If this game comes on sale and you like Star Wars or RPGs, definitely consider buying it.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												One of the best Star Wars licence game ever made and one of the best RPG games of all time. Period.There's little to be said about this masterpiece. Even being a 12 year old game, it didn't age too badly and still plays fantastically. Possible to launch it in 1080p with a bit of tinkering. Game is fairly unstable on modern OS and in one playthrough crashed about 7 or 8 times. Still, all technical negatives aside the game still feels wonderfully crafted. Endless dialogs, various quests, different and varied locations and choices with serious consequences - all these elements are only a small part of the whole KOTOR package. HK-47 is probably one of the best video characters BioWare has ever made, or even in general. Game does have it's flaws. For example: inventory system is really basic and once you start hitting 20-30+ hours into the game, and if you're a hoarder, it gets very difficult to find stuff that you need, since everything is thrown into one pile. Camera can take some getting used to, but overall won't be too much of a trouble. AI pathing is poor, ofter will your AI partners get stuck and you'll have to take control of them to make them move towards you again. Also your AI doesn't use health packs, stimulants, or any other consumable, half the time they don't even use their learned abilities. There is a "Script" option, but it's very basic, since you can't customize it, and it only offers 3 rudimentary options. Some of the above mentioned negatives are more or less nitpicks, since this is technically a turn-based RPG, so you are encouraged to micromanage everything yourself, rather than let the AI do everything for you. This might be a deal breaker for some, but I personally did not find it too difficult to setup fights with my party, while also controlling my own character. Game does have a pause, so you can always pause and take a breather if things are getting out of hand.As a 12 year old RPG game, it puts most today's RPG to shame with what it has to offer.A must have game for any RPG, Star Wars fan, or even if you just like great games.meatbag/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Now 13 years old, the affectionately nicknamed Kotor is still worth playing. Sure the menus are clunky and textures show their seams from time to time, but the meat of the game, the plot and the character development, is still fresh. The story arc, like with the original Star Wars trilogy, is better if you've managed to avoid key spoilers. Even knowing what's going to happen doesn't stop the journey there from being wonderful because the main plot is secondary to the events happening on the planets involved in it anyway. In true Star Wars fashion, the mission at hand has our heroes hopping from one planet to the next and each layover is focused around getting entangled in the goings-on of that place and its people rather than moving the plot forward.  Captions are a necessity as some speak in their native tongues, further driving home the fact that the galaxy doesn't revolve around you as the player. The world and its people feel alive, though the lack of player accommodation can get a bit tiresome.The world of Kotor may not be an 'open-world', but with a seedy card game-based gambling ring, a struggling racing circuit, and plenty of side quests, there are too many distractions to call it linear either. The same can be said for the physical act of playing the game as well. Straightforward violence with all its lightsaber dueling, blaster shooting, and Force pushing is always an option, and though it is a fantastic spectacle of parring and dodging, the fun of it wears out quickly. Thankfully, a number of encounters can be bypassed with a clever application of a character's skills. Computers can be hacked to shut down security systems, derelict droids can be repaired only to be sent against their former masters, and enemies can be persuaded to disband before a conflict even arises. For a game that was designed with the original Xbox in mind, there is a surprising amount of freedom in how the game is played.  That freedom is echoed in the game's approach to the player character's companions. Though only two can be chosen to leave the ship at any time, they all hang around and level up either way, meaning the dynamic can be altered to suit a situation as it arises. Simply talking to your companions can reveal a good portion of their character, but it's the personal quest each companion has that acts as their turning point. How players react during a personal quest will affect their compatriots for better or worse, providing some bit of control over their personalities, and giving the player the option of role-playing with the group dynamic in addition to their own created character. At its core, Kotor is about a group of heroes struggling against the dark side of the Force while traveling through hyperspace and interacting with a wide variety of alien species, just like any good Star Wars episode. But Kotor offers more than just lightsabers and blasters, and it never loses sight of the legacy it's adding to.
