content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												While the RPG elements may not be deep enough to completely satisfy more diehard players, KOTOR deserves its legendary  status as one of the greatest examples of the genre. An excellent soundtrack (composed by the renowned Jeremy Soule) compliments what is an exhilarating ride through the Star Wars universe, travelling to numerous planets all with their own visual style, enemies and inhabitants. Along the way you'll meet characters who can join your team and aid you in your bid to save the galaxy. Unlike most games, almost all of these characters are memorable and developed well to the extent where you find yourself considering your choices carefully so as not to alienate your favourite companion(s).On the subject of choices, KOTOR provides the player with extensive decisions to make, many of which have a significant impact on how the story unfolds. Many of these choices are built around the light side/dark side dichotomy, with each evil decision pushing you towards the dark side of the force and vice versa. These choices influence not only the story, but the effectiveness of equipment and force powers, many of which are affected by how much the player aligns with either the light or dark side of the force.Last but certainly not least is the plot itself. The narrative that this game weaves is widely considered among the greatest in video game history with a twist that (in my opinion) exceeds the famous "I am your father" scene. Simply put, this game is a must buy for anybody who doesn't have an irrational hatred for anything involving Star Wars.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is one of the most beloved Star Wars games to date. It takes place about 4000 years before the Rebellion destroyed the first Death Star. The game is an RPG (Based on the D20 system, meaning the game 'rolls' to see how much damage you will do at the current turn). Before you start up, make sure to familiarize yourself with RPG mechanics (For example, you will want to know what Fortitude is, or saves)The game has an average completion time of about 30 hours, and about 20 if you've played before. The story is one thing that is truly remarkable. If you haven't had the game spoiled for you, drop what you're doing and just invest your time into this, as it has one of the most compelling and unexpected stories you could find in the Star Wars universe.Pros-Long story-Story keeps you invested-Great variety of planets-Lot's of variety in playstylesCons-No native 1080p support-Few bugs on newer OS's (Windows 7 and above)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Now, 12 years since its release, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic still stands as one of the finest games ever wrought by the hands of BioWare, long before they were corrupted by the Sith Lord Darth Riccitiello and turned to the dark side.KotOR is a classic RPG with honest-to-god stats and skill points, an increasingly rare sight in these, the days of merciless streamlining. The graphics are obviously dated (but not an eyesore), and the combat finds a comfortable balance between simplicity and the necessity of pausing to issue commands to your party.To fans of the Star Wars franchise, the world of the Old Republic will be familiar, but also incredibly alien. Unsurprisingly, the writing is clumsy by modern standards, equal parts railroading and patronizing handholding. You get the sense that each line of dialogue was written to leave an opening for every question you can ask, and characters have no problem imparting upon you the same piece of information a dozen times over the course of a conversation. In spite of this, however, the world makes it incredibly easy to immerse yourself in it. Even with its shortcomings, KotOR is undeniably the genesis of the modern RPG, the proto-Mass Effect, and although you might not get it on with 100 year-old blue aliens, you can't help but feel that this is where it all began.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												Oh my god, this game is awesome! At first, it kept crashing during cinematics, but running it in windowed mode will fix that. This game's quite old, so it's also harder: it doesn't autosave frequently and dying will force you to load a save up to 30 minutes ago (so always save!). If you get past these minor issues, the game's absolutely wonderful. It's increadibly immersive with great character development and story progression. It's nonlinear, so you can have a different experience everytime you play. I've only played through it once so far and I loved it. KOTOR's got a feature that's missing from a lot of todays games, but I can't really tell what that is. If you're a Star Wars fan, this is a must play!

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												You know, every couple years you have one "pearl" in every kind of genre. 2003, BioWare and Obsidian gave us "Knights of the Old Republic" or short: "KotoR"And this game IS absolutly amazing. WARNING: May include spoilers, even though I´ll do my best to keep them out.KotoR plays like 4000 years BBY (for not SW Nerds: Battle Before Yavin, or 4000 years before "A New Hope").Darth Revan and Darth Malak, two heros of the Mandalorian war, a war that could´ve destroyed the Republic, return to the galaxy as new Dark Lord of the Sith. Darth Revan, the leader of the newly "build" Sith army wins one battle after the other, before he´s betrayed by his student Darth Malak, who wants to rule on his own. Now that we know a little bit about this games backstory (which is also included in the game and one central point of the plot), let´s get down to the mainstory.You´re a soldier (or one of two other classes), recruited for duty on the "Endar Spire". While you´re resting, the Endar Spire gets hijacked by the Sith army. You try to fight your way trough the enemy, while you do your best to reach the Jedi "Bastila Shan", an important role in this war because of her "Force Meditation". As you´re unable to find her, you make an emergency landing on the planet "Taris", which is confronted with a sith blockade. On Taris you´re trying to find Bastila and afterwards leave this planet. As soon as you found her (after doing some favors and a veeery terrible first 2-3 hours), you leave Taris and travel to "Dantooine". As soon as you arrive, your Jedi-Training starts and a long journey to save the galaxy begins...Even though KotoR is already 11 years old, it still has some good graphics to offer. Surely there are so animations that look kinda strange or even some textures which look "washed-out", but it´s still a pretty game. You travel to different planets, which all have their individual look. As we´ve seen in BioWares "Dragon Age 2", this isn´t something they´re always able to achive ;) Also, some of the characters faces look kinda mechanic. They have a disturbing lack of emotions, espacially your main character. Yet they´re able to eradicate this by having absolutly professional voice actors. The atmosphere created by a very typical Star Wars score, pretty graphics and  very well written (and spoken) dialogues is intense and believable, espacially as you´re reaching the end. Planets like "Kashyyk" create their own unique flair and are very well translated from the source-material. Especially the dialogues do a good job of delivering story, feels and atmosphere and serve a very wide variaty of emotions. But as we all know, that´s something BioWare has mastered over the years. The character editor is also nice. Even though you don´t have that much influence on the appearance (as you can only decide how your character looks by some different faces, without having much influence on them), but you´re able to build a charater you want through the variaty of stats and attributs. A good and fair skill-system keeps you motivated to level up and the (even though it´s very limited) customization of your weapons will enable you to create a very individual character. I won´t say much about the story, but.. it´s absolutly amazing. I finish this game at least once a year (also KotoR II: TSL, which in my opinion is a little bit better, even though it´s an unfinished game) and I´m still enjoying it. It keeps you motivated to go on, find all this different NPC´s and involves you in a story that (at it´s time) was a amazing thing for the SW franchise. I recommend you to buy this game and enjoy it. I´ratte it with an 8.6/10. It´s a classic. It´s an example for BioWares brilliance. Buy it now and you will have 20 hours of fun in a world that wants to be explored!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Here is my review of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic.As a huge Star wars fan it surprises me that it took me so long to play this game. I recently picked it up in the steam christmas sale for like 3 bucks. I played a couple days later to see how good it actually was. to be honest at first I absolutely hated it. the combat style was completely new to me and I had no idea about anything in the old republic era of star wars so I closd the game and didn't play it for another month. I opened it back up convinced that this game was something. I mean most people say that this is the greatest Star wars game ever, let alone rpg ever.I beat this game a couple hours ago and I have to say that this has been the best Star Wars game I have ever played in my life. Number one this game has an insane amount of content in it. I beat the main storyline in about 30 hours. Most games that hae come out recently don't have a storyline this long. The characters in this game are absolutely awesome to learn about and get to know through the game. the game incorporates a kind of moral system where decisions you make in the game effect whether you go to the dark side and go to the light side. This game has a very cool combat system (was you get the hang of it.) It is turn based so most people (at least me) was not used to this type of system. The graphics are very dated yes, but the game is by far playable. I honestly didn't really have a problem with them. But the best part of the game is that it feels completely "star wars" I really did feel as if I was imersed in the world of Star Wars.Now for cons of this game. In my opinion there isn't that many cons. The only ones I can think of is that your "bag" i guess or where you hold items in endless you can hold a million items if you wanted to which is cool but the items aren't very organized which is the con in this case. My other con is that after I beat the game I planned on doing all of the leftover side quests but when I beat it just rolled credits and I wasn't allowed to go back and do other things in the game which kind of annoyed me.My final rating of this game would have to be 10/10.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2012
												KOTOR (as the cool kids call it) is; put simply; a classic. If you've enjoyed newer BioWare titles such as Mass Effect and Dragon Age, you will enjoy Knights of the Old Republic. Following a battle system very similar to Dragon Age, KOTOR puts you in the shoes of a force sensitive character trying to survive, find his (or her) place in the universe, and deciding between the call of the light side or the pull of the dark side. Of course you've got to save the universe somewhere along the way.This game shines in always giving you the option to CHOOSE how to do things. Will you help that troubled person, or destroy them? Will you show charity, or rob the helpless of what little they have? Whether you are a Star Wars fan or not, this is a must play. Very few games give you an experience like this.The gameplay is no slouch either, with deep customization, party choices, and force powers to train and use. If you're a fan of RPGs, Star Wars, or video games in general, get this!

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Rating 7.5/10Overview: Turn Based RPGThe Good+ The game has a lot of robust options in how you build your character. You start by choosing between 3 classes, soldier, scout or scoundrel. Each class obviously focuses on different aspects of combat. Further in the game you can then choose the Jedi you wish to be: Guardian, Consular or Sentinel. You can fully customize your character how you wish between attributes, skills, feats and jedi powers. All of this leads to many different options and replaybility in how you design your character+The core aspect of the game is that as you can either play as a Jedi that is good or evil. Saving people, being kind and choosing the peaceful solution leads you to the light side while doing the opposite leads you to the darkside. Doing so leads to certain bonuses to your Jedi Powers. Being good means Lightside powers will use less mana and darkside powers cost more and viceversa. I find the system to be very effective because it ties morality choices into gameplay, a feature that seems to be very lacking in today's modern games. +The game supports a solid story that is engaging throughout the entire game. Dialogue is well done although a bit heavy on exposition in the beginning. +As is the case with every Bioware game, the supporting cast of characters are interesting and unique and features some of the best writing in the game. Getting to know your companions and there back stories is one of the highlights of the game. +The game has plenty of interesting sidequests that are fun to play and depending on how you solve them really start to shape your character. I wish there was more ambiguity with the quests because it becomes very obvious which is the good and evil way to solve them. A moral grey area would have made choices tougher to make.+ The game takes place across a series of planets within the Star Wars universe. Each location feels different from the last and has a rich back story that just adds to the authenticity. The AverageCombat in the game is basic, simply select your choice of attack then watch and hope your character can actually connect with a hit. It doesn't feel very engaging especially in the later parts of the game when you become really powerful. The game had many graphical glitches and bugs in certain areas that made it difficult to play.Final boss is frustratingThere are a lot of areas in the game that feel big and empty.The BadThe UI especially navigating to find items in your inventory is a chore and frustrating. The inventory screen is a long list of your items. Finding a specific item can be problematic, for example, if you find a data pad and want to read it, you have to open your inventory scroll through a long list of items until you find it. If you have other datapads in your inventory that you haven't checked yet then you have to check each one until you find the one you're looking for. There are options to filter the list based on specific items but this doesn't fix the overall problem of a bad overall inventory management system. ConclusionI have played this game many times before it came on steam and having it in my library I decided to play it again to see how well it holds up and I was pleasantly surprised. This game feels like the blueprint for Mass Effect as it shares many similarities in its design choices.

												Since the original posting of this review there now appear to be more trouble shooting resources than ever before. Steam has also improved refunds. I still do not recommend the steam version from personal experience and have had better success and instant playability with the GoG version on three separate computers.If you don't like trouble shooting this game probably isn't for you.I have found KotOR to be near impossible to play through steam. Some people may not have much trouble starting it but a majority are not able to get this game to run without spending a significant amount of time troubleshooting. The first time two years ago after nearly an hour of trying fixes the game finally ran after character creation. I was about two minutes in  but could not figure out how to progress. Turns out it was bugged. More troubleshooting and I manage to finally get to the next part of the mission only for it to be bugged again. After a few hours I could not get the game at any more playable of a state. One year later I give it another shot and this time I can't even get the first mission to load. Close to four hours of work and I manged to play five minutes of the game.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2013
												A game coming from the good days of Bioware, with a deep setting, and a shapeshifting plot. The story is riddled with plot twists, and the game is using a form of D&D in combat, so the D20 still reigns supreme. The visuals fare just fine, and the music is well-placed in the various locations of the game. Sure, there are a few occasional bugs, and some can be quite annoying, which, when combined with the game's above-average combat difficulty, can cause some headaches. But the drawbacks are largely overshadowed by the well-done aspects of the game. If you're a fan of the Star Wars universe or not is unimportant, since an excellent RPG is the same, no matter the setting. Buy it and do the old Bioware justice.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Set thousands of years before Luke Skywalker leaves Tatooine, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic sets you into a galaxy that is familiar, yet new and exciting at the same time. KOTOR is truly one of the best, if not the best, titles BioWare has put out. In fact, it is one of the best RPGs  on the market, and, needless to say, this a game that EVERY self respecting Star Wars fan needs to play. The characters are compelling, and the storyline is one of the best game storylines I have ever played. Even after all the years it has been out, the game still holds up as fun and enjoyable, and still gets multiple playthroughs from me. I cannot speak highly enough about this game. For anybody who wants a gripping and epic Star Wars storyline, this game should be at the top of your list to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Alright I'm gonna go ahead and say it, i love this game. Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is my favorite game of all time. The character creation is great and the way your character becomes stronger over fighting regular enemies, monsters, and even sith is amazing. The amount of fun you can have in this game is endless! The story in this game is by far the best writing by Bioware in my opinion. Especially the epic plot twist about your character when confronting Darth Malak, this game's Dark Lord of the Sith. The party members are fun to talk to and energetic, especially HK-47 and Jolee Bindo who are by far the most interesting characters to converse with. The first level in this game brings you in the middle of the action! And it hasn't even been five minutes into the game! The first "official" level is Taris the planet that you crash land on and it serves as a "tutorial level" but the shere amount of learning you have to do especially with help is incredible. The game will teach you about certain combat feats, control, different weapons and shields, and most importantly the alignment system. The alignment system is where you can choose to follow the light or dark side depending on what actions you take and what dialogue you choose to say. And it affects your personality, traits, and appearance! A light sided character will be helpful and looks "good" for lack of a better word, and a dark sided character will be demonic looking, evil, and will kill anyone they can for no apparent reason. Anyways, this game is by far the best Star Wars game I've played and its sequel is awesome as well. I recommend this game to any fan of the RPG genre and a Star Wars fan as well, and to any person interested in playing the game or getting into the series, try this game out it will be worth your time and money.

												In my humle opinion, one of the best RPG's and certainly one of the best Star Wars games ever to grace this world. I honestly can't find any flaws in this game (apart from the dated graphics, but that is of no concern). If you ever had a dream of being a brutal Sith, slashing your way through varied enemies, or being a noble Jedi, inspiring his followers and dealing out justice, then this is the game for you. All in all, if you are a fan of well-done RPG's or Star Wars, this is an absolute must.

												Still a great game after all these years, there's only a few real problems I can think of:* Controls are a bit fiddly sometimes. I've gotten stuck on invisible objects, and once somehow got trapped inside a door requiring me to reload a saved game.* The underwater section in Manaan is still horrible. Prepare to spend 5-10 minutes /slowly/ walking across the sea floor while wishing horrible things upon the developers. * The inventory system is a bit of a mess. Maybe it's because I loot everything I come across, but by the end of the game finding anything was a nightmare. Just way too much stuff and not many ways to sort it. Other than that this is still a great RPG 13+ years later. The voice acting is superb and the story is the most well written out of any Star Wars media I've come across. Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												It's been a long time coming but I owe this game and its successor, KOTOR II, a review out of respect and great love for the series. Years after I finished both games, a decade after the initial release, I can't help but to look back on what can be considered the greatest Star War games and the best the RPG genre has to offer. I entered the Star Wars scene only recently, after avoiding the franchise for so long, and these are the games that made me want to saturate myself in its lore and history. This in itself is a feat considering how outdated these games are. Needless to say, the graphics are old. I'd put them on par with games like Fallout: New Vegas, which is a similarly ageless classic that survived the test of time. I'd also say that the graphics here are somewhat better than New Vegas' in terms of lighting and color, and if I had to guess it's because of KOTOR's liberal of black and cleaner, darker color schemes. Regardless, the worth of a video game is not determined solely by its appearance or budget and that is not why either franchise is so spectacular.Enter the KOTOR realm of sci-fi fantasy, space-opera RPG goodness, with a complex universe, spades of history, and a plot that not only manages to pull everything off, but ultimately be coherent and fulfilling. Have you played a recent open-world RPG that promises to deliver freedom and a good time worth the money, yet feels somehow... lacking? Or even disappointing? The KOTOR games give all and more - and what I mean by this is that the story, character arcs and world are so complete that there's nothing that you can change about them. Others may disagree and say that's exaggerating, but it's clear that whoever wrote these games wrote them to its maximum potential, which is something sorely lacking in modern games, especially ones based off popular franchises. At least on a personal level, having played reknowned games like Skyrim and GTAV, this game is up there on the "most brilliant games I'll never forget" list.Like a true RPG, KOTOR is deeply ingrained with choices that matter. Your character matters. Your relationships matter, your words matter. Anyone who knows anything about Star Wars knows that a person's choices can lead them down the path of light or the fall to the Dark side. You can decide to be a Jedi, a Sith, or someone in between and all those around you will see and react and that affects the story. And I mean this in the literal sense that the story, scenes, and ending differ vastly upon the path you choose, not just some ending cutscene tailored to a few dialogue options in the game.Gameplay, like the graphics, is simplistic but in the end you just can't deny that double-sided lightsabers are awesome. More than the fighting, I enjoyed the exploration, though I hesitate to call it open-world. KOTOR is all about travelling from planet to planet and learning what each world has in store for you and your character.I was particularly impressed by the scope of history and design woven into these worlds, and perhaps this is because Star Wars is based on an amalgation of human cultures. The universe feels grounded, and that includes intergalatic space travel, special powers, and aliens. It's not in the science and realism of its universe, but the deeply human, emotional connections that are shared across the KOTOR and Star Wars saga among its many species. That's why this game is so highly rated. I can only compare this to universes such as Tolkein's - extensive and relatable even through its most fantasic moments - that you could make another ten movies or games of it and you'd still have material to spare.I played KOTOR II before the first one, and looking back I'm not sure why, but I actually recommend playing it in that order - KOTOR I has a (slightly) more linear story but features a certain plot event that I feel is the proper climax of both games. In any case, if you love Star Wars, or if you don't care about Star Wars but love science fiction (the games are nothing like the movie trilogies btw), if you love intense story-driven games that put you in charge of the story-telling, or if you just plain love a fantasic game, this is a game to remember. And what a fantasic game it is. Much love to Bioware and Obsidian, you are the creators of miracles and legends.

												A classic RPG in every sense of the word, KOTOR remains a seminal point in gaming history. With a unique vibe that can only come from the Star Wars universe, the story and gameplay of KOTOR hold up surprisingly well even today. It isn't the prettiest game at the ball -- and it's not without its missteps -- but I'd recommend RPG fans of any caliber to relive this slice of history if for nothing other than the geek cred and good times that can only be had with a lightsaber (or two) by your side.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Just finished this game for the 1st time after seeing that it was $2.99 on the Steam Holiday sale, & it's by far one of my top 5 RPG games of all time.Pros:I love how vast the Star Wars KOTOR universe is (especially for such an old game) & how the player can steer the game in any direction that they choose since there are so many ways the game can be played.Also, the character customization is great & the story is very solid & immersive. If you're a fan of Star Wars & love RPG-type games such as the Witcher series, then I highly recommend this game.Cons:In my opinion, the ending/s of the game was a little weak. It was very short, abrupt, & unsatisfying after playing through such a deep & immersive story to say the least.Also, once you finish the story, you can no longer free roam. Instead it takes you back to the main menu where your only options are to reload previous saves or start a new game. I wasn't a fan of this since I spent so much time upgrading my character & making him look cool just to find out that you literallty can't do anything with him after completing the story.Still an amazing game though! Highly recommend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I avoided STAR WARS - Knights of the Old Republic (SWKotOR) for a long time. Long used to WASD gaming it has an unusual but fitting control system that you quickly get used to. I freely admit learning it was the only part of the game that wasn't smooth, and even saying that it's very quick to get used to.Not long into SWKotOR I began to realise and regret that I didn't play it sooner. As a long-time STAR WARS fan, and with how much I enjoyed STAR WARS Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy & STAR WARS Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast on release date because of how well-made they were I should've known how good SWKotOR would be.Even now I'm surprised with how well-written the game was. I couldn't stop playing it, couldn't wait to see how the relationships with the other characters would unfold, couldn't wait to get started on the next side quest.The only gripe I had at all was that it was short - slowly pushing 100% of content played only took me a little over 40 hours.After you get to grips with the different controls you're going to love it if you're a STAR WARS fan of any kind.SWKotOR is an old, but superb game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												What can i say? This game is absolutely amazing from start to finish.The plot is very strong with some suprising twists which makes it interesting as well.The characters that follow you have their own background, and your companions may trigger an argument making it feel more alive!The combat is turn-based and easy to understand, with the ability to pause in the middle of the battle, giving you time to set up a strategy.Throughout the game, your actions will change who you are alligned with, whether its the dark side or the light, each having their own unique powers giving it some replayability.There are many side quests for you to complete ranging from interrogating to finding missing holocrons, adding a bit of variety.The only downsides that i give to this game are: the autosave sucks a lot, so make sure you save often to avoid any stress.The AI sometimes messes up, whether they block your way, they get stuck and rarely stop attacking and bugs out for a second or two.Overall i give this game a 9.5/10 because it is one of the best star wars games of all time. It has a lot of content for you to explore and learn the universe of star wars, i believe if you can bypass these cons, this game is a perfect 10/10 without a doubt.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2012
												Hands down, one of the best RPGs available for PC or Mac. Bioware (already renown for Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights) took the Star Wars universe and did it justice; proving it could make for a damn fine game. Whether you're a Star Wars fan or just a fan of the RPG genre, KOTOR is every bit worth owning.PROS:+Good amount of customization for protagonist and team members.+Choice between Light Side and Dark Side with every decision made within the story.+Huge, open-world exploration spanning multiple planets.+Non-linear story; both in terms of moral choices and the effects of some side missions.+Some cool mini-games, from Swoop racing to Pazaak (card game). +Endless REPLAY VALUE.CONS:-6th gen (PS2 era) graphics will annoy graphics snobs.-No multiplayer.-No Steam Achievements (yet).

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												There's nothing to not like about this game. Considering it was released some fifteen some years ago and is stil played is already a testament to how good it is. If I could redo my first play through, then I would. Nothing, ABSOLUTELY nothing, will beat the shocking revelation of who you truly are in Kotor. The sheer joy of receiving your lighsaber...after horus of grind...wow. You have to remember that at the time, games were usually very straight forward with what they wanted to achieve in terms of their story.I haven't played Kotor in years, and I'm glad to report that after some 8 years or so, this game is still very much fun.I also recommend you buy Kotor along with Kotor 2 because they're both brilliant games, consider them the Half-Life series of the RPG genre. Am I overexaggerating? Maybe, maybe I am, but Kotor just has a special space in my heart.Go get it, meatbags.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Effectively the main inspiration behind the structure of Bioware's Mass Effect, KoTOR to me is one of the greatest RPG's I've ever played. Even ignoring being a fan of Star Wars overall, it seems detached from almost everything else that has been produced (The Old Republic being based off a similar time frame), movies especially, and brings a lot of new things, despite keeping that semi-familiar setting.It shows it's age, though, with no widescreen video options, and (very surprisingly), no vanilla overhaul mod available to tweak it up. At the same time though, there's a big reason for that, and that is that it has very little in the way of bugs and problems, and looks good enough for a game over ten years old. Another big way of showing age is a lack of functions many have come to expect from RPG's, like some kind of auto-loot, there's no way to heal the entire party automatically.. But the variety of how you can approach situations is rather staggering (But rather expectable from Bioware nowadays)Definitely a great game, would recommend it to anyone who wants to lose a few weeks to a rather engrossing classic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												It's been a long time coming but I owe this game and its successor, KOTOR II, a review out of respect and great love for the series. Years after I finished both games, a decade after the initial release, I can't help but to look back on what can be considered the greatest Star War games and the best the RPG genre has to offer. I entered the Star Wars scene only recently, after avoiding the franchise for so long, and these are the games that made me want to saturate myself in its lore and history. This in itself is a feat considering how outdated these games are. Needless to say, the graphics are old. I'd put them on par with games like Fallout: New Vegas, which is a similarly ageless classic that survived the test of time. I'd also say that the graphics here are somewhat better than New Vegas' in terms of lighting and color, and if I had to guess it's because of KOTOR's liberal of black and cleaner, darker color schemes. Regardless, the worth of a video game is not determined solely by its appearance or budget and that is not why either franchise is so spectacular.Enter the KOTOR realm of sci-fi fantasy, space-opera RPG goodness, with a complex universe, spades of history, and a plot that not only manages to pull everything off, but ultimately be coherent and fulfilling. Have you played a recent open-world RPG that promises to deliver freedom and a good time worth the money, yet feels somehow... lacking? Or even disappointing? The KOTOR games give all and more - and what I mean by this is that the story, character arcs and world are so complete that there's nothing that you can change about them. Others may disagree and say that's exaggerating, but it's clear that whoever wrote these games wrote them to its maximum potential, which is something sorely lacking in modern games, especially ones based off popular franchises. At least on a personal level, having played reknowned games like Skyrim and GTAV, this game is up there on the "most brilliant games I'll never forget" list.Like a true RPG, KOTOR is deeply ingrained with choices that matter. Your character matters. Your relationships matter, your words matter. Anyone who knows anything about Star Wars knows that a person's choices can lead them down the path of light or the fall to the Dark side. You can decide to be a Jedi, a Sith, or someone in between and all those around you will see and react and that affects the story. And I mean this in the literal sense that the story, scenes, and ending differ vastly upon the path you choose, not just some ending cutscene tailored to a few dialogue options in the game.Gameplay, like the graphics, is simplistic but in the end you just can't deny that double-sided lightsabers are awesome. More than the fighting, I enjoyed the exploration, though I hesitate to call it open-world. KOTOR is all about travelling from planet to planet and learning what each world has in store for you and your character.I was particularly impressed by the scope of history and design woven into these worlds, and perhaps this is because Star Wars is based on an amalgation of human cultures. The universe feels grounded, and that includes intergalatic space travel, special powers, and aliens. It's not in the science and realism of its universe, but the deeply human, emotional connections that are shared across the KOTOR and Star Wars saga among its many species. That's why this game is so highly rated. I can only compare this to universes such as Tolkein's - extensive and relatable even through its most fantasic moments - that you could make another ten movies or games of it and you'd still have material to spare.I played KOTOR II before the first one, and looking back I'm not sure why, but I actually recommend playing it in that order - KOTOR I has a (slightly) more linear story but features a certain plot event that I feel is the proper climax of both games. In any case, if you love Star Wars, or if you don't care about Star Wars but love science fiction (the games are nothing like the movie trilogies btw), if you love intense story-driven games that put you in charge of the story-telling, or if you just plain love a fantasic game, this is a game to remember. And what a fantasic game it is. Much love to Bioware and Obsidian, you are the creators of miracles and legends.

												A classic RPG in every sense of the word, KOTOR remains a seminal point in gaming history. With a unique vibe that can only come from the Star Wars universe, the story and gameplay of KOTOR hold up surprisingly well even today. 												To this day, this is one of my favorite games. I could put this game next to an award winning, brand-new release and still love this game more. It takes everything you want from the Star Wars universe, and everything you want from an RPG, and merges them together. The story is enticing, the characters are all unique and interesting, and the gameplay is just plain fun. I mean, who doesn't want to become a Jedi? Or a Sith, if you so choose. Basically, don't be thrown off by the release date. Don't shove this game aside because it doesn't have the same features as some newer games. Just buy it and take a chance. 												Alright I'm gonna go ahead and say it, i love this game. Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is my favorite game of all time. The character creation is great and the way your character becomes stronger over fighting regular enemies, monsters, and even sith is amazing. The amount of fun you can have in this game is endless! The story in this game is by far the best writing by Bioware in my opinion. Especially the epic plot twist about your character when confronting Darth Malak, this game's Dark Lord of the Sith. The party members are fun to talk to and energetic, especially HK-47 and Jolee Bindo who are by far the most interesting characters to converse with. The first level in this game brings you in the middle of the action! And it hasn't even been five minutes into the game! The first "official" level is Taris the planet that you crash land on and it serves as a "tutorial level" but the shere amount of learning you have to do especially with help is incredible. The game will teach you about certain combat feats, control, different weapons and shields, and most importantly the alignment system. The alignment system is where you can choose to follow the light or dark side depending on what actions you take and what dialogue you choose to say. And it affects your personality, traits, and appearance! A light sided character will be helpful and looks "good" for lack of a better word, and a dark sided character will be demonic looking, evil, and will kill anyone they can for no apparent reason. Anyways, this game is by far the best Star Wars game I've played and its sequel is awesome as well. I recommend this game to any fan of the RPG genre and a Star Wars fan as well, and to any person interested in playing the game or getting into the series, try this game out it will be worth your time and money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												One of BioWare's earlier achievements, KOTOR's an easy game to criticize in retrospect. From the release of Baldur's Gate in 1998 to Mass Effect just 10 years later, most every RPG released by BioWare would follow the same mass-produced, literally by-the-books Hero's Quest outline—i.e., each game’s plot felt like a meeting of forced expectations, sometimes satisfying and sometimes mind-numbing in their predicted delivery—a choice that simultaneously made their products restrictive holds against and necessary stepping stones for advancing the depth possible in video game story-telling.But who cares, right? KOTOR tells a generic Star Wars story with mostly generic Star Wars characters, meeting every generic Star Wars expectation a gamer could ask for right down to the tired, required lines, but it does so almost flawlessly, to such an extent that its seemingly pedestrian qualities make it among the most fun and accessible modern RPG experiences and Star Wars stories. In an age-old formula so noticeable and so repeated some players even refer to it as "the BioWare Cliché," a faceless variable with a background too vague and mysterious to be taken seriously, recognized by everyone around them as vitally important is thrown into the midst of a universal conflict against a threatening Force of Unfathomable Evil. As their life is turned upside down against their better judgment, they’re guided by close mentors friends, one of whose personality’s teeters on the edge of simply being Han Solo before he’s overcome by emotional turmoil (and the personality traits are thusly handed off to a snarky youngster and her wookie companion), the other a sassy, sexy Obi-Wan-Leia hybrid.* Through thick and thin, unsurprising twists and heart-wrenching betrayal, they form a series of close bonds and pass the required tests necessary to rid the galaxy of malice once and for all.Dropping the vague references to clichés repeated, KOTOR stars a young nobody, canonically male, her past just barely customizable to the point of ineffectuality, being shipped under unspoken circumstances that end under the galaxy-wide Jedi Civil War igniting her hidden potential in the Force (à la Luke Skywalker) over an introduction spent making friends and escaping the occupied planet-city Taris. Under the tutelage of these newfound friends, she hones her skills in the Force, strained physically and morally under four major tests of heroism across beloved planets like Tatooine and Kashyyk. What she and her entourage seek, they seek in the footsteps of the Sith Lord Malak and his former master Revan—deceased: betrayal, Siths, &c.**—, piecing together an alien map in order to understand what massive power source drove those two to Team Slytherin, or, like, whatever.Their fall is itself a story existing partially outside the game’s bounds, a series of events that took place after the culmination of the Mandalorian Wars—the galaxy’s previous Big Mistake and a war led by the war-mongering culture of Mandalore, a bone-headed, unlikeable civilization modeled after a single facet of humanity, their sole goal to enslave or destroy everyone just because. The backdrop of this war’s aftermath fuels the chaotic political state in KOTOR; it was a war in which the Jedi stood by, watching—idling on the decision of whether their place included interference—and yet a war won almost single-handedly the two previously-mentioned Jedi, rationalizing the need to defend freedoms and lives threatened by Mandalore’s conquest.Krayt dragons, wookie tribes, life debts, Klingons, Jawas and their sandcrawlers, planets being razed from space, half-naked old men running around star ships, limitless sources of unimaginable power, lost alien civilizations, bland villains—KOTOR has everything you expect and love from a Star Wars tale, wrapped and guided by the massive conflict of good and evil fighting over mythopoeic indulgence. The central theme of mythology itself, abused by Lucas and now by BioWare, here works as a symbol of their aging morality mechanics. Following this game, treading those grey areas became a duty, even if it took a couple stories and universes to figure out how to present believably.As an RPG born in 2003, it almost can’t help but tread that line between oldschool and new-, providing a strategic (but accessible, simplified) battle-management system that lets you plan the course of every encounter at your own pace, coupled with real-time decision-making and exciting action full of lasers and light sabers and lightning-quick force powers and, uhm, grenades, I guess—just with dice rolls, added and appreciated: beloved mechanic of chance in things past. The leveling system also stands as one of BioWare's most fluid and functional (opposed to, say, Mass Effect’s messy, meaningless overdose of options and numbers), letting players tread lines however customizable they can get to the point of breaking the game, i.e., as with many RPGs prior to this last generation, it’s not exactly difficult to customize your character to the point that whatever plot point is impassibly difficult, i.e., multiple save files are strongly suggested. And as such an RPG, it took some shocking dares in character design: HK-47, the fan-favorite assassin droid prefaces every delivered line with the emotional intent behind them, creating a stir of always-contemptuous black humor and irony; and Jolee Bindo, whose entire presence—a good man sitting comfortably on the line between the series’ Dark and Light Sides, quick to point out the flaws (and outright stupidity) inherent in the tenets of the Jedi Knight code—hints at the brilliant postmodern deconstruction Star Wars would get in Obsidian's ambitious sequel. They let us know lead-author Drew Karpshyn was capable of a lot more than farting out game-y dialogue and fetch quests by the dozens even when limited by that bullet-point list of Quest-with-a-Q requirements.That greyed-out line Jolee walks, also brings to the forefront major flaws in BioWare’s championship of the modern RPG format. Areas of grey don’t apply much outside of his character or even BioWare’s RPGs prior to Mass Effect 2, but the forceful impact of choice has been their calling card (& often selling point) since 1998. When choice arises in dialogue or action, the writers strive to bring the sense that you’re calling the shots, that you’re the acting force that shaping its conclusion. Those choices, unfortunately, amount to either following that path of charity and sacrifice defined by the Jedi code, or make your avatar sound like a cartoon jerk tossing out petty insults like candy--maniacal laugh included. Under this system, choices often amount to little more than variations on the lines “I’d love to help clothe and feed you!” or “I don’t have time for your stupid babble.” This never makes sense with whatever narrative is being told: E.g., Why would these characters follow these bad decisions? Why would this person fall in love with this monstrous cliché?Are these aged mechanics and writing a bad thing? I would definitely argue No, despite the lingering force of Internet backlash BioWare gets from more critical players. The ambition driving this illusion of meaning in player choice has only improved and grown more bewilderingly ambitious with every game BioWare’s released, the massive steps taken between each a necessary movement culminating in (as of 2013) the phenomenon that is the Mass Effect trilogy, a series driven successfully by the player choice and personal involvement all their previous RPGs like KOTOR strived towards. It may have taken a lot of trial-‘n’-error gambits—still ongoing—but it doesn’t mean the errors are necessarily mistakes, and it certainly doesn’t mean they aren’t worth experiencing when they’re this danged fun.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2013
												A game coming from the good days of Bioware, with a deep setting, and a shapeshifting plot. The story is riddled with plot twists, and the game is using a form of D&D in combat, so the D20 still reigns supreme. The visuals fare just fine, and the music is well-placed in the various locations of the game. Sure, there are a few occasional bugs, and some can be quite annoying, which, when combined with the game's above-average combat difficulty, can cause some headaches. But the drawbacks are largely overshadowed by the well-done aspects of the game. If you're a fan of the Star Wars universe or not is unimportant, since an excellent RPG is the same, no matter the setting. Buy it and do the old Bioware justice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2012
												Hands down, one of the best RPGs available for PC or Mac. Bioware (already renown for Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights) took the Star Wars universe and did it justice; proving it could make for a damn fine game. Whether you're a Star Wars fan or just a fan of the RPG genre, KOTOR is every bit worth owning.PROS:+Good amount of customization for protagonist and team members.+Choice between Light Side and Dark Side with every decision made within the story.+Huge, open-world exploration spanning multiple planets.+Non-linear story; both in terms of moral choices and the effects of some side missions.+Some cool mini-games, from Swoop racing to Pazaak (card game). +Endless REPLAY VALUE.CONS:-6th gen (PS2 era) graphics will annoy graphics snobs.-No multiplayer.-No Steam Achievements (yet).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I played through this game, it's storyline is rich and creative and backed up by some brilliant voice acting and graphics especially for a 2003 game. I will not spoil the story but it has an excellent ending and interesting plot twists which the user will not expect. It is a fantastic chapter in the Star Wars universe and I highly recommend it to any RPG fans as it truly makes the genre hard to better, again for a 12 year old game it is unbelievably addicting and will have you playing the game non-stop until you finish.It has replayable value as you get to choose your own path, light side or dark side you have the choice entirely and conversational structure in the game allows you to make these decisions.Puzzles feature heavily throughout the game and are challenging with little aid, personally I struggled with them and had to research how to solve them online but they can be easily figured out with some effort. The characters in this game are unique and loveable, they aid the protagonist throughout and help influence your decisions if you allow yourself to fall into this game's smart trap of wanting to make your companions happy so you make decisions based on their interests.Overall I would put this game into my top 5 list of games ever, and it easily has one of the best storylines of any game I've encountered as an RPG fan.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Set thousands of years before Luke Skywalker leaves Tatooine, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic sets you into a galaxy that is familiar, yet new and exciting at the same time. KOTOR is truly one of the best, if not the best, titles BioWare has put out. In fact, it is one of the best RPGs  on the market, and, needless to say, this a game that EVERY self respecting Star Wars fan needs to play. The characters are compelling, and the storyline is one of the best game storylines I have ever played. Even after all the years it has been out, the game still holds up as fun and enjoyable, and still gets multiple playthroughs from me. I cannot speak highly enough about this game. For anybody who wants a gripping and epic Star Wars storyline, this game should be at the top of your list to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. When this game released many moons ago I was a young teenager. I have never played an RPG before and even worse: I did not know this game was an RPG. Unaware of my ignorance I placed the game into the the disc tray of my Xbox and never looked back. Since the release of the game I have over 1000 hours of play time between the Xbox and PC version. But what makes this game so good?Firstly is the the story. From the first second you feel a level of immersion that I find hard to get with other games. What makes the story even more enjoyable is that each playthrough you can do things differently and experience something new.Character customization has almost everything I could want in a game. While there are restrictions with physical appearance in character creation everything else seems to disregard it. The leveling system is beautiful with enough options that ensure every character you create will be different if you try. I find myself being immersed with the Equip screen as well, sometimes going through my equipment just to see what I will look in various armors/robes.The gameplay itself is satisfying. Using a real time turn based combat system, you rarely feel things are moving slow. While in combat you have the ability to pause the game, if you wish, and issue up four commands for your companions to perform. Experimenting with this can be fun to see what type of damage you can do and how quickly you can kill harder opponents.Overall, I would highly recommend this game for any Star Wars or RPG fan. Knights of the Old Republic is a milestone in gaming and everyone should try to experience what it hast to offer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a third person rpg set 4000 years before the events of the first movie. It starts off with you being able to customize your character to be either male of female and choosing your class. Afterwards you get into the actual game as your ship is immediately being attacked and boarded by the Sith. You are quickly overwhelmed and crash land on the starting planet. The planets and environments are one of the best features to the game. They are all very unique and offer lots of room to explore. You can converse with most alien species since your character speaks nearly every language under the Republic's domain. Some speak in their native tongues and you understand via subtitles but man do they talk slow. It could take upwards to 20 seconds for every sentence as they grumble and grunt their language at you which made me very glad there is an option to skip sentences with the click of the mouse. It's usually worth talking to them as they explain their culture, problems and feelings on the war between the Republic and the Sith.Your companions on the other hand are some of the most annoying and broody bunch of support characters I've ever seen. Don't get me wrong a few are actually really cool but it would be nice to kick most of them out of your base. You can take up to two of them with you on missions and you can equip and dress them however you like. They will sometimes trade quips or add their opinions into a conversation which helps flesh them out more. An alignment system is in place where you can either focus on the light side by doing good deeds or the dark side by evil ones. It's not just a superficial system, being on the light sides makes casting dark side powers a lot more difficult for you to cast. You can also be neutral but it is pretty hard to maintain. Which makes for a lot of interesting circumstances on whether you want to help someone due to being dangerously close to steering toward the light side which has nowhere near the strength of the dark side powers. We don't start of as a jedi and don't have these powers at the start of the game but it is something to keep in mind. Gameplay consists of auto-attacking and clicking on abilities to either damage or heal. There is an option to pause time and set commands to each of the party members which lets you use plan your battles far easier than trying in real time. At times your character will just freeze up and not do anything while enemies get free shots in. Happens rarely but is infuriating when it happens in a brutal fight. A glitch that happens a lot more occasionally is being unable to move after a battle. It fixes itself after 30 seconds of not doing anything but with the amount of battles in this becomes a real problem. Activating Vsync fixes this problem for some people. You can use a shield a limited amount of times, throw grenades, lay land mines and use force powers which makes for a lot of variety. Never gets old seeing a  Jedi get fed up with fighting a group of enemies and just throws a grenade.  Melee combat is pretty cool as well, they have a preset fighting animations where they kick, dodge and slash at each other. You have no control over it but it definitely adds more action to the fights. Ranged has a single animation where you dodge some blaster rounds but starting off your aim is so bad that it would make a StormTrooper blush.Outside of combat you can explore, disarm landmines and pick locks considering you have the skill to do so. You can gamble in some kind of modified version of BlackJack but you need to collect the cards of the deck yourself. You can also join Swoop races that play like your modern day runner. There are also turret sections on occasion where you can defend your ship from an attack fleet. On top of all that there are a ton of side quests and having done nothing but what I was required to I still got 31 hours out of the game so as you can see it is a very lengthy game. Most of the time you will be in dialogue with another character and given multiple ways to answer or deal with dilemmas. Unfortunately the voice acting ranges from mediocre to terrible and considering the amount of talking you do it may be a bit of a turn off to some. That is the only thing wrong with the sound side of things. The music has a mix of original Star Wars music and some newly composed music that all sound excellent. The sound of blasters, electrocuting people and lightsaber fights all sound great as well.  Story is kind of dull. It starts off promising but quickly devolves into a treasure hunt for maps.  Occasionally you will get a cut-scene of the villain sending some useless goons to hunt you to remind the player he even exists. The story really picks up near the end of the game though. You'll mostly be interested in the politics of each planet and the troubles they are going through like trying to stay neutral in the war, slavery and criminals controlling everything. Your choices have some pretty big impacts like medicine costing much more credits (money) to everyone, yourself included. It is definitely the type of game you play for the adventure instead of the grand overall plot.  Graphics are obviously dated with character models looking very ancient but the environments themselves look decent.  The menus are awful. You can pick up as much stuff as you want without limits but everything in the inventory is seemingly placed at random,without ways to quickly reach a category of weapon or to sell junk it really becomes a chore. You will have to change weapons since some are much more efficient against certain types of enemies and would have been made so much less frustrating by a decent menu.It is a good game don't get me wrong but it is not the greatest rpg ever that some people claim it to be. I had quite a bit of fun with it and will immediately play the sequel after this review. I am not a Star Wars fan though so that may be a fact to take into consideration.  Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a fun game dragged down by some technical and  user interface issues but still manages to be a game worth considering if you are into the genre.It's also nice to see a Star Wars game not including Obi Wan or Luke like most games and you can tell they put a lot of effort into weaving their own identity into the Star Wars universe. It still holds up against the rpgs of today and shouldn't be dismissed due to it's age.

												Seriously let me just be completely honest here. This game is amazing, but Can be a pain at times. The game itself is absolutely amazing and it has a wonderful story that any starwars fan should be enthralled by. HOWEVER! The fact remains that this game is extremely dated and it has a lot of problems when it comes to computers. It can be as I would put it "whiny" and crashes a lot for some people. The game is so outdated that it literally thinks some pc parts are older than itself or it cannot recognize them. I know many work around for this issue and they are on the forums, but it is still a pain. Beyond that, the graphics and some of the sounds are pretty iffy, but since it is 10 years old you should expect that. I would still recommend buying this game even if you wait for the steam summer/winter sales where it is 5-10 bucks. (US) It is seriously worth it even after all of the problems behind it. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												What can i say? This game is absolutely amazing from start to finish.The plot is very strong with some suprising twists which makes it interesting as well.The characters that follow you have their own background, and your companions may trigger an argument making it feel more alive!The combat is turn-based and easy to understand, with the ability to pause in the middle of the battle, giving you time to set up a strategy.Throughout the game, your actions will change who you are alligned with, whether its the dark side or the light, each having their own unique powers giving it some replayability.There are many side quests for you to complete ranging from interrogating to finding missing holocrons, adding a bit of variety.The only downsides that i give to this game are: the autosave sucks a lot, so make sure you save often to avoid any stress.The AI sometimes messes up, whether they block your way, they get stuck and rarely stop attacking and bugs out for a second or two.Overall i give this game a 9.5/10 because it is one of the best star wars games of all time. It has a lot of content for you to explore and learn the universe of star wars, i believe if you can bypass these cons, this game is a perfect 10/10 without a doubt.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												By far my favorite RPG of all time. Quite literally now when I play an RPG I hold it up to the standards of this game, which isn't usually a good idea because this game isn't easy to beat. I still enjoy playing through it again and again, it just doesn't get old. The story is so filling, it's hard not to get drawn into it. I know some RPG's you have to focus or constantly try to put yourself in the protaganist's shoes, but Knights of the Old Republic does it for you. It opens the door for you, grabs your coat, sits you down on one of the best chairs on earth, hands you a beverage created by George Lucas from up in the cantina in the sky, and tells the best story you've ever heard. Quite literally, if you haven't played this game yet, you're the equivilant of a bantha fodder. Don't know what is? Even more of a reason to play this game. What are you waiting for? Just buy it. You won't regret it.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												A classic RPG in every sense of the word, KOTOR remains a seminal point in gaming history. With a unique vibe that can only come from the Star Wars universe, the story and gameplay of KOTOR hold up surprisingly well even today. It isn't the prettiest game at the ball -- and it's not without its missteps -- but I'd recommend RPG fans of any caliber to relive this slice of history if for nothing other than the geek cred and good times that can only be had with a lightsaber (or two) by your side.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												I am now 26 years old, twice as much as I was when I first played this game. I was already impressed with Bioware's Neverwinter Nights at the time, but the hundreds of hours I spent on KotOR really set the bar for all future RPGs for me. Features you love games like Jade Empire, Mass Effect, KotOR 2 and Dragon Age or even Arcanum, The Elder Scrolls and newer Fallouts for were pretty much all introduced to me by KotOR. A great soundtrack, deep companion stories, good/evil choices that make a difference in the storyline, plentiful side-quests, plot-twists, they're all there. This game was certain to become a classic the moment it hit the shelves in the second half of 2003.Definitely among The Essentials.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												When I first got this game in a bundle, I was hyped to play it because I've heard it's amazing. Sadly, I just couldn't get it working because of some compability issue with Windows 7.I tried everything: disabling hardware mouse, disabling movies, turning off Steam's in-game overlay, lowering the resolution, even some mods. I gave up after some time because it was just too much work.Yesterday I talked to a Steam buddy who said I had to play this game because it has one of the best plots in the history of video games. So I downloaded it again and had the same problems I had back in July. I was determined to get it working and even though it took me some time, I got it working. Soft shadows were the main issue. I couldn't ♥♥♥♥ing believe it, the game crashed all the time just because of soft shadows!?Okay so that may help someone here.I'm about 5-6 hours into the game now and it's pretty cool, kinda hard though.UPDATE: Played through both KOTOR games, this one is amazing 8.5/10. The only thing wrong with it is it's kinda a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get it working, but believe me it's worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I avoided STAR WARS - Knights of the Old Republic (SWKotOR) for a long time. Long used to WASD gaming it has an unusual but fitting control system that you quickly get used to. I freely admit learning it was the only part of the game that wasn't smooth, and even saying that it's very quick to get used to.Not long into SWKotOR I began to realise and regret that I didn't play it sooner. As a long-time STAR WARS fan, and with how much I enjoyed STAR WARS Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy & STAR WARS Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast on release date because of how well-made they were I should've known how good SWKotOR would be.Even now I'm surprised with how well-written the game was. I couldn't stop playing it, couldn't wait to see how the relationships with the other characters would unfold, couldn't wait to get started on the next side quest.The only gripe I had at all was that it was short - slowly pushing 100% of content played only took me a little over 40 hours.After you get to grips with the different controls you're going to love it if you're a STAR WARS fan of any kind.SWKotOR is an old, but superb game.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												Seriously let me just be completely honest here. This game is amazing, but Can be a pain at times. The game itself is absolutely amazing and it has a wonderful story that any starwars fan should be enthralled by. HOWEVER! The fact remains that this game is extremely dated and it has a lot of problems when it comes to computers. It can be as I would put it "whiny" and crashes a lot for some people. The game is so outdated that it literally thinks some pc parts are older than itself or it cannot recognize them. I know many work around for this issue and they are on the forums, but it is still a pain. Beyond that, the graphics and some of the sounds are pretty iffy, but since it is 10 years old you should expect that. I would still recommend buying this game even if you wait for the steam summer/winter sales where it is 5-10 bucks. (US) It is seriously worth it even after all of the problems behind it. (Be aware that the second is even worse off with those issues for some people.)

												10/10 would play a thousand times again.Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a game that I would recommend for everyone and anyone to play. I've followed this game for years, from playing it on the xbox to buying the game and playing it here. This game has amazing replay quality, in depth character development (for you character and any other that you interact with), amazing variety in planets and spieces you can interact with, along with tough decisions and quick thinking. There are so many side quests to complete, each providing you with with more information about the galaxy and the conflict between the Sith and the Republic. Each time you go back to play you discover more and more quests that you missed the first time. You really can never get bored.So please, throw down the 10 bucks or less it costs, download it, play it, and love it. I swear you won't regret it :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
 Includes slight spoilers for some main and side-quests; I played through the game at least three times before I purchased it on Steam  Knights of the Old Republic - Review You are going to hate Knights of the Old Repbulic no matter how much enjoyment you gained from playing it. There is one simple reason for this: The moment the credits roll, you’re going to realize you just finished one of the best games ever made. And this can never be undone.4000 years before the battle of Yavin: You wake up aboard the Endar Spire amid a battle against a Sith-Fleet. Just like you, your character has no idea what the hell just happens and where he is. But behold, there is the unsung hero Trask Ulgo who is kind enough to explain the situation and the basics of the game. This is how the best Star Wars game ever created starts. From a modern point of view, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic might seem outdated. Its graphics pale in comparison to recent roleplaying games like the Mass Effect, The Wichter or the Dragon Age Series (all these titles are great in their own regard). But fancy graphics don't matter. KotOR puts heart and soul into its characters, plot and ultimately its dense atmosphere. And in one swift stroke BioWare pulls off what George Lucas never managed to do with the prequels: To tell a story of grand scale that is nonetheless personal and adventurous. Simply put, it creates a story that lives and breathes the original Star Wars. But you don’t need to be a huge Star Wars fan to adore this title as it is a great RPG, too. If you enjoyed Mass Effect or Dragon Age, KotOR is for you. The roots of the former titles can be traced back directly to the latter. Elements that were introduced in KotOR were later refined in these games. Your character is mute (just like in original Dragon Age). Every other character is fully synchronized. Some people are bothered by this and I can fully understand that but it offers the advantage that there are a lot more dialogue options than the recent BioWare-ian triad of “good”, “neutral” and “evil”. And, of course, this helps to bring some of the most memorable characters of video game history to life. You might’ve guessed it: The characters of this game are just amazingly well written. Every one of them brings something different to party. Every one of them is unique. And every one of them is memorable. I still can recall dialogues with every party member and that is no incident. Conversations are the beating heart of Knights of the Old Republic. Especially the ones with your crewmembers are excellent. Sometimes, they are dramatic. For example the quest that revolves around Bastila Shan’s parents. Other times they are hilariously funny – especially the conversations that involve a certain droid. Even the banter between your party members during missions is well written. BioWare manages to create some of the most beloved characters of the Star Wars Universe and with that they shaped the so called “Expanded Universe” for years to come. Credit must also be given to the beautiful voice acting by everyone involved. Naturally, this is also connected to the excellent storyline which offers one of the most shocking plot twists ever created. But truth to be told: The mission goals might get a bit repetitive during the mid-game. Nevertheless the steps to achieve the goal vary stark due to highly entertaining side-quests and level-design. For instance, during one main quest you are accused of a crime and have to defend yourself. If you do something wrong, they'll sentence you to death. In another mission you have to finish the training to become a Sith. Furthermore your quest leads you to highly diverse planets from the vast deserts of Tatooine to the tightly populated planet of Taris with its urban vibe that is reminiscent of Coruscant. The tremendous score by Jeremy Soule just enhances the experience - he carefully mashes up well-known tracks from John Williams with his own arrangements to create a unique soundtrack, that is deeply rooted in the realm of Star Wars compositions and yet highly distinguishable (listen to Bastila Shan's theme for reference).Besides the old-school-graphics, the gameplay probably discourages most people from picking it up. Admittedly, it’s slow as it is round based. That means you have choose an action your character takes after the enemy “finished his round”. It’s nothing like Mass Effect where you are actively aiming and shooting. If you want to boost the challenge, you stop using the pause button and choose an action for every party member. You don’t have to, though. The game is not very hard if you just want to enjoy the story. However, some boss fights can be really annoying on the first try.If you think about playing Knights of the Old Republic, do yourself a favor and just do it. You won’t be disappointed. If you generally like BioWare games or Star Wars you should play this as it was a defining game for the former and the latter. Tl;dr: KotOR combines a cast of great characters, a compelling story with some unpredictable twists and turns with polished gameplay. Conclusion: Play it, meatbag.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Knights of the Old Republic is one of my top games of all time. I knew nothing about the game until it released, and picked up my first copy on the Xbox because it was Star Wars, and I liked Star Wars. At the time, I had no idea what I was getting myself into, but years later I look back at the few years I spent with this game as some of my golden gaming time. I've beaten the game with practically every party configuration and gone for every ending, torn through every sidequest, and I used to beat the game in one sitting. One particularly fond memory of mine involves picking it up one summer evening in high school and not stopping until the next evening when I was watching the end credits roll. I soon had a PC copy at my disposal and played it through some more. It was also the first piece of DLC I ever downloaded, Yavin Station for Xbox... which came natively with the PC version, since it was released later.All that aside, the game has both aged well as a great western RPG, but it hasn't aged well in the sense that it hardly cooperates with modern systems and it loves to act goofy, crash randomly, corrupt your saves, and sometimes just do inexplicable weird things. The port wasn't good back in the day, and it isn't good now. The controls are a bit funky, but they suffice... although the mouse/keyboard acts funny. Unfortunately, there is no easy way to get a controller working on it, and the game was definitely designed for a controller. If you want widescreen, prepare to either do some heavy ini editing, or download Flawless Widescreen... and even then, it's wonky and doesn't like to work properly all the time. When it works, though, KOTOR looks glorious and like it has hardly aged.The game was definitely an inspiration for the eventual Mass Effect, with a very similar overall feel to how the game flows, except the combat is a d20 DnD ruleset. It feels a little off, but once you get the hang of pausing battle to issue commands, it works great. My biggest gripe here is that unless you are micromanaging your party, they tend to do stupid things like pull the next pack of enemies down the hall while you're trying to recover. Speaking of managing your party, the game hardly gives you a reason to use non-jedi characters once you get them, although the single best reason to not have three Jedi in your party is HK-47... who is definitely worth having in your party as he is possibly one of the funniest video game characters of all time. Another party issue - [you must gather your party before venturing forth] is a message you're going to become very familiar with. There is also a ton of boring walking to do in this game, back and forth and back and forth... that used to be more normal, back in the day, to have a ton of walking from location to location in a game, but nowadays with things like fast travel cutting the general patience levels down, it can get boring when you have to walk very far to turn in a single sidequest for a paltry 200 XP.I also take a issue with the some of character building in this game... I'm going to warn you, don't waste points levelling up feats like blaster proficiency. This is one of those games that likes to give you a ton of options, but many of those options are ultimately useless and hinder your character later. It's tough to totally gimp yourself at least, but you can very easily waste a ton of points on things that absolutely do not matter.The story is the gold here; KOTOR tells an amazing tale with a fantastic twist and an ending that is rather satisfying. You can go for the Light Side or the Dark Side, and the game actually radically changes depending on whether or not you're Dark or Light. One of my favorite examples includes a mission early in the game where you can either help a widowed woman by buying an item her husband had hunted for her at an inflated price to give her a hand, or you can be evil and force persuade her to just give it to you. Some missions change entirely, such as either slaughtering an entire base full of people willing to help you, or gaining their trust and joining their side to help clean up the sewers.Overall, I think this is definitely worth checking out if you've never played it, but be ready to be patient, and keep multiple rotating saves. There are a ton of bugs here, sometimes the game will corrupt your save for no good reason, and sometimes you just might end up with an irreversible game-killing bug in the form of a friendly Galaxy Droid entering your ship. It's unfortunate that Bioware and EA have all but forgotten that these games exist, because they could definitely use a patch to make them more cooperative with Windows 7, widescreen resolutions, and generally not being a nuisance with modern machines. If you have played the game before, you know what to expect here. It's an amazingly wonderful western RPG, one that still stands as an excellent game over ten years after release.
