content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Revan, Bastila, Carth, Mission, Zaalbar, Juhani, HK, Canderous, and Jolee would form the crew of the Ebon Hawk, and together, embark on a journey unlike any other in the Star Wars Universe. One that is a tale of friendship and hope. A saga of darkness and light. An examination of morality and corruption. A study of past sorrows giving way to future joys… all these things and more. Framed by the journeys of Revan, who wanted nothing more than to keep the galaxy and those he loved, safe. Together, the crew would endure the trials of Tatooine’s Dune Sea, uncover the mysteries of the Utopian society of Manaan, trudge through the thick worshyr forests of Kashyyk, and encounter, first hand, the power of the Dark side on the Sith academy of Korriban. Piece by piece, planet by planet, they would complete the Star map. And with it, their destinies as peacekeepers of the galaxyThank you Revan for a beautiful childhood,Thank you Bastila for showing how much the light side of human nature is stronger,Thank you Knights of the Old Republic

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Knights of the Old Republic (KoTR) for short, is an epic Star Wars RPG that lives up to the name. This game plays as a bioware should, basic morality choices are the focus of dialouge and dice-rolling DnD style rules for the combat. Its deep enough to get lost in purely for the game itself, yet doesn't let this depth ruin the Star Wars immersion. Though a short story for RPG standards, its fufilling and satisfying. Its old, but its definately a staple in any good library.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2012
												I saw this review sitting here and wanted to flesh it out, so here is what I'll leave it.This game is amazing. If you want a good story with a wonderful plot that fits the star wars feel this is exactly the right game. It doesn't have much in the way of dialogue trees, but it makes up for it with an amazing story. I find myself going back seeing what content I missed last time or how I could do something differently.This game may not do anything new (besides a specific point in the plot I am not going to spoil) but it is a worth while game to play, especially since it leads into the second game. The series itself is well thought out and puts you in a wonderful DnD style world.My only issue with this game is the fact that getting it to work on modern PCs is a chore. Usually involving swapping out the MSS32.DLL file, disabling videos, and even patching the game to get it to run at a 16:9 aspect ratio. Regardless of this though, the game has withstood the test of time and I would (and have) recommend it to anyone who even asks about it.OLD REVIEW:This game has amazing graphics, can work on almost any machine, and has one of the best stories I've ever seen. This is a great game with a lot of replay value, and I would reccomend purchasing it. This game does have some trouble with Windows 7, and graphics cards with ATI Support, although it does not make the game unplayable.I would rate it:9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I don't know many hours this thing says I've played, but it's wrong. I got this game when steam didn't even exist and it is the epitome of what games ought to be: worth the damn money.Obviously it's Star Wars, so it's got that whole world going for it, even if it is now part of a disavowed canon. But beyond that there isn't a lot happening that was ground breaking for RPGs (maybe the decision based morality system, but I am not certain about that). So why should you buy it and play a thousand hours?The story.It's a compelling story of redemption if you want it to be. It's a compelling story of fate if you want it to be. It's just whatever you want it to be. Add in all the mods currently available and it is literally whatever you want it to be. Also, the restored content mod adds originally designed items and quests that got left out because LA loves to rush their♥♥♥♥♥♥to the market before it's finished.I mean, if you want to "be a Jedi", there are better games. Battlefront. Jedi Knight II. To an extent, the Force Unleashed series. All of these let you control more of the force powers and have something more akin to actual saber combat. But this game is all about the story:Sith versus Republic, a band of warriors brought together to fight for (or against) peace, and a mysterious stranger recruited to help defeat (or supplant) the Sith apprentice become master, Darth Malak. You travel to worlds across the galaxy in order to figure out how the Sith are building their fleet more quickly than the Republic can defeat them. And with the addition of the "grey" Jedi, those who are neither light nor dark, maybe you decide it's best to sweep away the remnants of the Galactic Republic and rule it yourself.I mean, it's not canon anymore anyway. Do what you want.Recommended Buy, but only on sale because it goes on sale so often. It's worth the extra money, but I believe in you and your ability to exercise self-control until it's 75% off.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												One of the greatest RPG's ever made, KoToR is not just that, but it'also the greatest Star Wars game ever made. It's a must play for Star Wars fans and Bioware fans. For Bioware fans, it's fairly similar in the formula of playing a character that is set on a task of saving the world/universe from the forces of evil, in this case, the Sith, while there is also the moral choice of following the dark side here, as well. But Bioware fans, more specifically, Mass Effect fans, will find it familiar for the numerous side quests, the collection of companions and taking two with you at a time. You get to a point where your companions travel through space with you on a ship and, like Mass Effect, the companions are located in various points of the ship.Yes, I know, this game came out years before Mass Effect, but not everyone played it back then, and it should still appeal to a mass audience now. I'm glad the game is on Steam, as there are ways to get the game to play in full 1080 HD/16:9. It involves editing text files and running a patch, but it works and shouldn't be an issue, if you know what you're doing.The plot, amazing. I shouldn't even have to talk about it. You play a soldier that wakes up in the middle of battle on a ship and you fight your way to the escape pods with your bunkmate. Along the way to escaping, you meet Carth, whom will become your closest ally for the rest of the game, and unfortunately, your bunkmate dies, sacrificing himself so you can escape. Carth, and yourself crashland on Taris in the escape pod, and from there, your wild adventure begins. From Taris, you find work, make money, figure out what's going on between the Republic and the Sith, meet various companions, the Big Z (a wookie) and Mission (a twi'lek). You meet the mercenary Canderous and eventually you get to learn how to race and finally, you meet Bastila, a Jedi who becomes your second closest companion.There are more companions in the game, but I'd be diving into the story and other planets. As for your character, you uncover the fact that you are strong in the force and train to become a Jedi. And soon, you're on a  mission to save the world from the evil Sith, and Darth Malak, a formidable foe, and one hell of a boss. (I died too many times on the final fight, prepare to have plenty of medpacs)Overall, this game was insanely awesome.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												As a big fan of the Star Wars Franchise I’ve delved into the expanded universe through reading some of the novel’s watching the movies and television shows and of course playing the games. As with the other Star Wars games I was very excited to try this one out. The title ‘Knights of the Old Republic’ just brought up fantasies of fighting with a lightsabers and force powers, exploring galaxies, and enjoying a deep and captivating narrative. I am happy to say that all of these fantasies came true. SWKOTOR is not only one of the most enjoyable Star Wars videogames, but it lands in my top five of videogames of all time.From start to finish the player is just captured by the World, characters and gameplay systems implemented in this RPG. You start off as a soldier, scout or scoundrel and end as a guardian, sentinel or a consular of the light side, dark side or even somewhere in between that. The story has a good twist near the end of it and is perfectly paced. The other characters in the game are fully realized, having their own backstories and missions, making this Star Wars experience so satisfying and engrossing.The combat system is smart and allows for a wide variety of strategies that will have to be thought out by you to emerge victorious. You are almost always allowed to have two other characters with you in a party as you explore the planets in the galaxy. You’re allowed to save your progress at any time and can talk to pretty much anybody. There are also two other side activities to do that are actually quite fun in addition to the side missions. The first of these side activities involves a card game called pazaak where you can win, or lose some credits. The second comes in the form of land speeder racing circuits which are available on three of the planets. You can also win a considerable amount of credits doing this. These credits can be spent at different stores and cantinas on weapon mods, armor enhancements and such. You can upgrade your weapons and armor via workbenches found around the world and on your ship, yes that’s right you get a ship, how else would you travel the galaxy at will? They thought of everything for this game and implemented it in the best way possible. If you love role playing games you should definitely set aside some time to play this, I have played this three to five times on the original Xbox and plan to play it some more on the PC, I strongly advise you to do the same on the PC since you’re reading this.This is my favourite RPG to Date, and possibly the best Star Wars game ever created.10/10I’d give it 11 if I could

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
9/10Necessary PurchaseIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!Pros+Environments


STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™ 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™: Knights of the Old Republic™
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




The spectacular environments and areas that this game creates are absolutely unmatched. From the sprawling cities of Taris to the water-based metropolis of Manaan all the way to the Blood-red sands of Korriban this game has some breathtaking areas that I just cant do justice with words. No matter where you are there is always something to look at,something to see,or something to do. The characters also fit with where they are seamlessly.+WritingThis game has some absolutely phenomenal writing,from listening to a traitor give his passing words to and old friend all the way to hearing the hilarious jokes spewed from my meatbag-hating friend's grated mouth;this game has some incredibly memorable dialogue that will either demolish you with feels or leave you dying of laughter.+GameplayThis game uses a very tactical style of gameplay. You que up the actions of each of your 3 characters in the party and can also que different items such as energy shields to deflect blaster shots,or medpacks to heal grievous wounds. You'll end up needing all sorts of items like these to survive the toughest of fights in the late game. There are plenty of fights where you simply cannot win without some heavy thinking,using adrenals to buff your party, and using energy shields to absorb damage. This adds an element of intelligent planning before each fight. You cant just run in and play the game in real time,as even on easy this proves quite a challenge. You need to pause the game at the beggining of each encounter and think about how you are going to approach it.The boss fights in this game are incredibly well made,from suprises with bounty-hunters to encounters with hostile fleet command each encounter feels strategic and well thought out.+Character DevelopmentIn this game you play as Revan and the development of your character is astoundingly well done. You can either become a paragon of the light, or a beserker of the darkness.Either way by the end of the game you become a powerhouse,throwing your lightsaber to cut down any in your path or just straight up butchering them with dark side powers such as "Death Field" and "Force Choke". No matter what you do,the choices you make and the characters you influence,either through intimidation and threatening or persuasiveness and kindness,and your alignment with the force heavily influences the characters you meet and the ending you recieve.Cons-InventoryThe inventory is critical in an RPG and this one is pretty bad in multiple ways. First there is no semblance of order in the inventory screen. Everything seems to be ordered by type and even then im not sure about that. Ive had multiple occaisions where I pick up a datapad and have to scroll through my inventory,find the section of 5 items all named "Datpad",and find the new one.-CameraBoy this is the most infuriating camera I have ever had the displeasure of using. Trying to move around in close areas just ends up with the camera going all wack and you running around like a chicken with no head.-MovementMaybe its just the game being old but the movement in this game really aggravates me. Having to walk around instead of just turning around gets to be pretty annoying in tight quarters and the more enclosed areas. The movement in general just feels clunky as it is.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												This game is more Star Wars than most of the Star Wars movies. The story and characters and everything surrounding it is best experienced played, so buy it and play it already.Sure, the combat is a little dated, takes some getting used to, and has some infurating moments when you misclick, but it's weirdly fine having a real-time turn based game and fits well in most fights. The only real problems I had were near the end when I had no med packs and got bombarded by an absurd amount of sith but I got through eventually.Typical with most Bioware games, even before EA, there's a ton of choices that feel meaningful but you essentially get the same base story no matter what choice you make. I like this instead of vastly different outcomes because it means I only have to play the game two or three times to get the full choice effect, not 50 times to see every ending.Anyway buy this game, play it, love it, deny Disney when they say it's no longer part of the universe because to me this will always be.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
  Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic  Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, or KOTOR, is by far one of the best games I have ever played. It has recieved over 40 Game of the Year awards, and it is what I believe to be one of the all time great RPGs. Basic Plot You start off by waking in a starship, the Endar Spire, under attack by the Sith Fleet that have bombarded the Republic. You will make your way to an escape, whilst fighting through Sith soldiers that have boarded the vessel, meeting two characters on the way, one of which is the war hero, Carth Onasi. You and Carth flee the ship and crash land on a nearby Planet, the urban world of Taris, where you will start your search for Bastila, a legendary Jedi without who the Republic would be all but finished.After you find Bastila, you and many other characters you meet on your way, travel to Dantooine once discovering a cunning plan to escape the Sith quarantine on the planet, due to the help of Canderous Ordo, an ex-mandalorian (Mandalore in KOTOR 2), in the nick of time as the Sith armada begin bombing the planet once they learn of Bastila's whereabouts on the surface.Once you reach Dantooine, the main plot is revealed and you set off travelling from system to sytem on your quest, which will lead up to an epic finale. Features The amount of detail is astonishing for a game that came out in 2003, and you will find no better storyline or characters anywhere else in the Star Wars Universe, and in my opinion, in any other RPG. The graphics are not amazing, but I believe that they are appealing and the game is extremely atmospheric, partially due to the great ambient music. The story is essentially linear, however you get to choose the path you take, what ending you will have, and your actions have influences on other characters and NPCs, which can often be very rewarding and satisfying.Few small glitches and bugs, and it has turned-based combat, which may not appeal to some, but offers a more strategical outlook on combat. Also, this game is relatively dialog-heavy, however it is extremely interactive, with little in the way of characters droning on and on.It is likely to take around 28 hours to complete the game first time, even for more experienced players due to the main story and sidequests. Pros & Cons Pros:-Amazing Story-Interesting Characters-Feel like you are in control, e.g. character influence, path choice-Strong atmosphere-Plenty of playtime-Great replayabilityCons:-Handful of annoying (but minor) bugs-Aged graphics Final Score -10/10 - Would get arrested on Manaan againOverall, the best £7.99 I have spent (I would have payed easily £60 for this, now I know what it is like). The screenshots really don't do it justice, and if you like excellent stories and/or Star Wars, play it.

												10/10 would play a thousand times again.Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a game that I would recommend for everyone and anyone to play. I've followed this game for years, from playing it on the xbox to buying the game and playing it here. This game has amazing replay quality, in depth character development (for you character and any other that you interact with), amazing variety in planets and spieces you can interact with, along with tough decisions and quick thinking. Anything you say or do can change everything and keeps you on your toes.Just because the game is old and the graphics aren't the best, don't judge the game just on that. You can invest hours upon hours into this game and never be bored. There are so many side quests to complete, each providing you with with more information about the galaxy and the conflict between the Sith and the Republic. Each time you go back to play you discover more and more quests that you missed the first time. You really can never get bored.So please, throw down the 10 bucks or less it costs, download it, play it, and love it. I swear you won't regret it :)

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												KOTOR is a great game with an amazing story and character development as well as solid voice acting. Bioware has been crafting these aspects of games right for a long time. This game also has a stellar sense of environment for its time in regards to the planets you visit: each area has a distinctive and memorable atmosphere and adjoining characters. The music, geography, encounters, and side-quests all make each area an amazing experience on its own.The component that makes this game a must-own and a classic, however, is its story. The fact that you have true agency over certain situations through dialogue is engaging and makes for a unique gaming experience. The parts of the story that you don't have control over still create such a compelling narrative that truly inhibits emotion - something that many games tend to lack.While no one needs another review to confirm that this game is a classic worthy of any and everyone's library, another voice to support is always helpful.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
 ONE OF THE BEST RPGS OF ALL TIME	In short, KOTOR is a legend. A game that you should buy just to witness the story. It has a well deserved place in my TOP10 best games of all time list. Search for TOP10 RPGs of all times and you will see KOTOR there in any list that is worth mentioning.Like all Bioware games, this game  heavily relies on the story. You wake up in a ship that is under attack and from that on try to save your own skin. On the way you meet good friends on different planets who have rich background stories on their own. 3 of the characters in this game found a place in the Most Popular Star Wars Characters of all time list by Lucas Arts Fans. Especially you will have incredible moments with HK-47. There are usually many ways to complete guests and depending on your actions the future of people and even nations change in the end.WARNING. Dont read any spoilers about this game before your first playthrough. There is a moment in the game that is selected The Most JAW BREAKING MOMENT of all time. It is such a moment that made me stop playing the game because of the shock and made me think how that is possible for a week.Fighting is amazing. There are 3 classes which effect your play stile a lot. Soldier is the typical fighter class while others are a little different. You are a jedi but you are allowed to focus on guns with high dexterity. You can queue 3 actions for each character while fighting for an easier management. I remember the easy difficulty was too easy so avoid that unless you are only into the story.I still love the graphics and the soundtrack is a piece of art. Character voices are very well done. I am still inlove with Jennifer Hale as the voice of Bastila Shan and it still makes me smile remember HK-47 saying MEATBAGs.In conclusion if you are a RPG fun, its highly likely that you already bought the game. If not, then this is the game that willl make you a RPG and Bioware fan.  Graphics 88   Music/sounds 95   Gameplay 90   Story 100   Replayability 90   OVERALL 98

												A very, very, very good game, great value for money and definately worth a buy. A unique story and a brand new set of characters makes it a breath of fresh air for even the most dedicated Star Wars fans, and it keeps you guessing with it's fair share of plot twists. It's also a great RPG on top of that. It's easy to get to grips with the mechanics and if you manage to get a few hours into the game the story really starts to develop, and the fact that it's a great RPG in itself makes it playable and understandable by even those who don't know much or even anything about the Star Wars universe. In my opinion, and many others, it's the best Star Wars game ever made, and one of the best RPGs. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												The first of two classic sci-fi RPGs that birthed the creation of the popular MMO, it had great graphics and gameplay for it's time.  Combat tends to follow D&D type rules while still providing action-packed fight scenes.  It tends to follow the set formula of most Bioware RPGs (generic hero with obscure origins and special abilities thrust into an on-going war of good vs. evil, add morality meter and companions, etc.), but contains a number of plot twists and a hefty dose of Star Wars lore.  Both the MC and his/her companions tend to expereicne significant character development as the story progresses, a portion of which the player can influence, leading to some intresting scenes and dialogue in-game.  All in all a classic title, and a must-have for those who wish to delve further into those events that helped shape the world setting of SW:tOR the MMO.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												PROS:+Excellent story. By far the best in any video game in my opinion next to the first Deus Ex. Also has a bunch of unexpected and genius twists that kick you in the balls and make you say "What the hell?"+Brilliant yet simple combat system based on the D&D dice roll system.+Lots of customization for you and your crew.+Lovable characters that you actually see develop through in-game dialogue selections(except Juhani)+Decent graphics for a 2003 game.+The planets you visit are diverse and extremely fun to explore.+Large range of weapons and powers+Light side and dark side alignment choices are present (you can be a saint or a♥♥♥♥♥♥ your choice).+Has HK-47, the slyest and murderous son(or droid?) of a gun that you MUST purchase when you're in Tatooine if you want to laugh all the way to your final fight with Darth Malak. Also has Jolee, the sterotypical old black man that makes you crack up at his sarcastic antics.+Mods support, but why modify an already amazing game,CONS:-Lots of bugs.-Pazaak, the most unfair and unbalanced variation of the game Blackjack/21-Podracing gets old.-Juhani, the most emo character in Star Wars history. I half expected her to burst out singing "Crawling."To be honest who gives a damn about the cons. Just get this game if you want to immerse yourself into a 50 hour campaign of lightsaber duels, firefights, well rounded characters(except for you-know-you) and the best Star Wars story, hell even the best story in a video game.10/10

content:
Posted: January 13
												Unlike most, this is a review coming from someome who never played this game until a few days ago.MAN! Even though I never played this game as a kid, I wish I had. I let this game slip my mind constantly for years until finally purchasing it last week. Pros:-Amazing story, with a twist around every corner.-Great yet simple combat system (Especially for 2003).-Interesting group of potential companions, most of whom have an interesting backstory.-Beautiful scenery, even though the quality is a little low there are many sights to behold on each of the 7 planets.-The ability to CHOOSE your side, and ending light or dark side.Cons: -Companion A.I. can get a bit clunky and frustrating as sometimes they'll run and attack someone far away when you're clearly trying to go the opposite direction.-Enemy A.I. will sometimes glitch and stand still, allowing you to attack them until they die. (Not really a con in most cases ;))Overall this game made me feel like a kid again, which is something I've never been able to say about any other video game. Would absolutely recommend to ANYONE who is interested in video games and Star Wars.P.S. F*ck you Manaan for banning me from your planet.Love,An angry Sith Lord

content:
Posted: January 15
												Over 10 years later and this game is still well worth the money. The combat is a little dated and might take some getting used to but the story, companion characterization and voice acting are top notch. Each area feels new and unique and you can feel the progression of your character as you move through the story.If you  have managed to avoid major plot points thus far I strongly recommend not reading anything else about the game. You're in for a fun ride.I had a couple of minor technical issues running this on Windows 10 but if you don't mind doing a couple quick google searches for problems you encounter (controlled character getting stuck after combat, ect.) you should have a relatively easy time.If you are someone who gets hung up on aesthetics (the game came out in 2003, cut it some slack) or are unwilling to do basic type and click research this may not be the game for you as you most likely will have to fiddle with some of the graphic settings to get things running smoothly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
A really, really long time ago in a galaxy far, far away...STAR WARS - KNIGHTS OF THE OLD REPUBLICRIP Star Wars EU (1977-2015)If the Star Wars Galaxy represented the old canon, the EU would be the Outer Rim. Unstable, conflicting, weird and somehow able to be amazing or downright terrible at times, the Old EU always has been a "Wild West", Outer-Rim of sorts where content quality was in the hands of outside contributors, many of them with no other reason than to make a few quick credits by flashing some yellow crawl text and John Williams fanfare before the drivel that they push out.Enter Disney, AKA The Galactic Empire, bringing law and order to the far reaches of the galaxy with its crack team of licensing and merchandising agents, reining back in the Star Wars creative universe with a heavily copyrighted iron fist. Now, with the scum of the galaxy flushed out of the airlock, and the original trilogy hoisted again upon a pedestal, supported by the raging hard nerdboners of millions of OT fanboys, we have peace.But forget not the glory days of the Old Republic.Knights of The old Republic, along with other works such as The Zahn trilogy felt like unessecary casualties of an overzealous purge by Disney. Although many absolute stinkers deserved to be booted from the canon, some of them were legitimately worthy of taking on the Star Wars name as extensions of the stories told in the movies.Star Wars' story has always been motifs and plot points that repeat and echo throughout the whole saga. It's like poetry, y'know. They rhyme. KOTOR is no stranger to that. On the surface, its story is the story of Star Wars, of a chosen one destined to bring balance to the force, defeat the baddies, get the girl and save the day!The game plays like an old fashioned, traditional rpg. Having never played any of Bioware's older rpgs, I found the gameplay to be really dated which lessens the fun somewhat. Case in point, the only direct player actions in combat are basically selecting a target and queuing up your attack orders or force powers, everything else being a dice roll. The user interface is clunky, with too much data hidden behind too many buttons and menu screens that draws the player away from the game. However, I cannot fault the game for simply being old, spoiled as I have by more polished and refined mechanics from newer titles.Where the game truly shines is the role playing and story.  Being a Bioware RPG, you start from a central hub, first a planet, later your starship, where you can select your party and choose to travel to different locations. You can pursue the main story by visiting any number of different planets, all of them giving off the distinct feeling of a unique place in the Star Wars galaxy. The characters that you meet along the way, your party members, all have a story to tell, and the choices you make reflect who you truly are. The plot heavily revolves around the concept of discovering who you are, and what you are versus what you want to be. Every quest decision and interaction with other characters affects not only their perception and relationship with you, but also your own morality. The game employs a meter that starts you off in the middle and every decision you make skews you towards either the light or the dark side. I absolutely love the option of either being a goody-two-lightsabers light side jedi or being a ruthless, Revangeful Dark Lord.Although the game was fantastic when it first released, does it still make sense to get KOTOR today? It's a given that its dated combat, graphics and gameplay cannot hold a candle to later RPGS like The Witcher or even Bioware's own Mass Effect series. However, if you are an avid fan of Star Wars, I would definitely say yes, just for the experience of being a Jedi or Sith, choosing the Light side or the Dark, in hands-down the best story experience ever in a Star Wars game.Which makes it in my eyes the second-best Star Wars game of all time. TIE FIGHTER GOAT *cue TIE Fighter screeching noises*~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ARBITRARY STAR RATING : 4/5 STARS~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I got this game from my grandma for Christmas when it released. I never really had any experience with RPG games and I was really young but I could understand the dialogue well enough to love it. I'm still very young today but back then, the game felt so epic and HUGE! I felt like each planet would take days to finish when in reality it only took a few hours. This was the only game I would ever play, I had to have replayed it over 40+ times and this isn't an exaggeration! Once KOTOR 2 came out I just had to get it, the game was fun but not as memorable as KOTOR 1. I remember being actually scared at points in this game. When I arrived to Malachor V, I literally was frightened to play it. The atmosphere and music was so grim and well done! Yesterday, I found my original XBOX along with both games, I checked my save files and WOW, did I play a lot of this game. The music is so nostalgic and a masterpiece! I decided to replay both games and it still holds up today as my favorite game of all time! KOTOR will forever be in my heart.﻿ I could write an entire 5 page essay on the game because of so much more I have to say about it. But I'll leave it at this, and I highly highly encourage you to try out this game. It may seem kind of stale to todays standards, but back then, it was next-gen. This was the only game that I played in my childhood, and I probably played it for 4 years straight without ever getting bored of it. Please give this game a chance and even the sequel the same. One other thing I would like to mention is how emotionally invested in the characters you can get into this game. I was attatched to multiple characters and they felt like they were my friends in real life. I haven't ever had this feeling until recently, with the masterpiece "The Witcher 3", and honestly, it's amazing.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												This game has been around for quite a few years now. It is one of the best RPG's out there, along with it's sequel, and hands down a must-play if you are a Star Wars fan!Currently, the movement can be a bit buggy. I don't recall this as an issue when I played it back on Windows XP years ago, but simply switching to one of your other controllable characters allows the other character to move out of the terrain glitch. I have only had the very rare crash so far in 20 hours of gameplay (I think twice). This game has a decent story, and plenty of weaponry to choose from. It allows both melee and ranged (blaster/bowcaster) gameplay, and the combat is turn-based in real-time, while still pausable at any time in the game to allow control of your characters and their combat options. There are times when you might come across a group of enemies to eliminate, during which your first attempt might end in complete failure, and minimal losses to the enemy; whereby approaching with a different strategy / different abilities, you may not lose a single companion, and find the fight much easier. Such is the combat mechanic depth.Graphics I can't say much about due to it's age, but they are good enough on the Steam version of this game to at least scale somewhat to to a widescreen configuration. In other words, the game is very playable (albeit not with the graphical content or depth of, say, Assasin's Creed).Absolute 10/10And if you enjoy this game and it's playstyle, then absolutely recommended is the sequel!!!! Happy Gaming!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20
												I've been a fan of Star Wars for many years, and I've played many of the franchise's games. Some of them provide excellent action ('Republic Commando', 'Jedi Academy'), but none of them are memorable in the way that 'Knights of the Old Republic' is. In fact, the only Star Wars game which I think approaches it in terms of quality is its sequel. The premise of 'KOTOR' is fairly simple: You play a soldier whose mission it is to stop a powerful Sith Lord, and in order to do so you have to find several components of an ancient map. It may sound like a cliché RPG, but on your travels you'll encounter so many interesting people, fascinating stories and incredible quests, you'll never want it to end. I know I didn't.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24
												This is an attempt to make a spoiler free review from a modern perspective for people unsure as to whether to purchase the game and are unfamiliar with it, but it is, of course, my own opinion, and an informed consumer should look at multiple reviews before buying.Gameplay: The game follows a D&D style turn based combat system, which can either be fun or needlessly boring depending on your preference. It is not a very difficult game to beat, either. Most enemies are there for the sake of being there to slow you down and/or give you something to do. Difficult fights that require you to scratch your head and mix up your approach are few and far between. Don't get me wrong, that does not necessarily make this an unenjoyable experience, but those who wish for a challenge will be dissapointed. In between combat you will focus mostly on dialogue (WARNING: there is A LOT of dialogue in this game; if you are not a fan of listening or reading lots of text, it is unlikely that you will appreciate this game very much), though you will probably also be doing quite a bit of inventory management and min-maxing of equipment, too. Skills in this game are usually used to aid in combat or dialogue (i.e. repairing droids to help in fights, using persuade to get more money out of a quest that you were given, etc...) Apart from that there are several optional mini-games but that about sums up what you actually do.NOTE: It's very useful if you go into this game knowing how basic D&D or D20 RPG systems operate so you understand what all the stats mean. You might have some trouble getting a grasp of the systems without knowing anything about that.IMPORTANT NOTE: This game has difficulty running on anything newer than Windows XP. It's probable you'll have to do some troubleshooting to fix issues playing the game, especially with cutscenes.Story and Quests: The main story in KOTOR is good,  but is unlikely to be that life-changing or awe inspiring for anyone, and its big twist can be seen coming for some time if the player has been paying close enough attention to all the dialogue and story thus far. The main plot also begins rather slowly and takes quite a bit of time to develop. This is not the game for the impatient and easily bored. Sidequests typically are, again, good, but not great. There are some real gems in there, though. I mean, it's a Bioware game. Perhaps the biggest strike against it is the binary morality system. You tend to either be the nicest and most compassionate person in the galaxy, or be a psychotic space Hitler. That being said, the game is classic Star Wars in design, so it's likely that is purposeful, but you should still be aware you are unlikely to be morally or ethically challenged or questioned in any way during this game (very much unlike its sequel, KOTOR 2).Characters: I'm giving this its own section because I feel like it deserves it. Optional party member quests and dialogue are a large part of this games overall story. Most party members in KOTOR are not particularly interesting, and it's likely you'll only do the backstories for characters you do find interesting. But most of this is entirely optional, so it doesn't really count as a strike against the game, and is a nice addition.Sound: Music is by Jeremy Soule so of course it's good. It is not classic John Williams, however. Take that as you will. It can either be good or bad.Graphics: Very dated. I don't feel the urge to go into greater detail as you can just look at screenshots above.Aesthetic: It is mostly bright and colorful without overdoing it. Nothing particularly stands out here. It's vibrant where it wants to be vibrant and dark where it wants to be dark. I don't really have anything to compare it to. Again, I recommend just looking at screenshots.Conclusion: It's a very good game, and definitely worth playing if you enjoy this style of combat and are patient enough with the story. You don't even need to be into Star Wars to have a lot of fun with this game.TL;DR: It's a quintessential Star Wars story (albeit a very slow paced one) mixed with D&D style gameplay and sidequests. If that sounds like something you'd like, you will probably enjoy this game. Be aware that if you try to run it on anything newer than Windows XP you can have problems, especially with the cutscenes. You may have to do some troubleshooting to get it to work.

content:
Posted: January 13
												Unlike most, this is a review coming from someome who never played this game until a few days ago.MAN! Even though I never played this game as a kid, I wish I had. I let this game slip my mind constantly for years until finally purchasing it last week. Pros:-Amazing story, with a twist around every corner.-Great yet simple combat system (Especially for 2003).-Interesting group of potential companions, most of whom have an interesting backstory.-Beautiful scenery, even though the quality is a little low there are many sights to behold on each of the 7 planets.-The ability to CHOOSE your side, and ending light or dark side.Cons: -Companion A.I. can get a bit clunky and frustrating as sometimes they'll run and attack someone far away when you're clearly trying to go the opposite direction.-Enemy A.I. will sometimes glitch and stand still, allowing you to attack them until they die. (Not really a con in most cases ;))Overall this game made me feel like a kid again, which is something I've never been able to say about any other video game. Would absolutely recommend to ANYONE who is interested in video games and Star Wars.P.S. F*ck you Manaan for banning me from your planet.Love,An angry Sith Lord

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Revan, Bastila, Carth, Mission, Zaalbar, Juhani, HK, Canderous, and Jolee would form the crew of the Ebon Hawk, and together, embark on a journey unlike any other in the Star Wars Universe. One that is a tale of friendship and hope. A saga of darkness and light. An examination of morality and corruption. A study of past sorrows giving way to future joys… all these things and more. Framed by the journeys of Revan, who wanted nothing more than to keep the galaxy and those he loved, safe. Together, the crew would endure the trials of Tatooine’s Dune Sea, uncover the mysteries of the Utopian society of Manaan, trudge through the thick worshyr forests of Kashyyk, and encounter, first hand, the power of the Dark side on the Sith academy of Korriban. Piece by piece, planet by planet, they would complete the Star map. And with it, their destinies as peacekeepers of the galaxyThank you Revan for a beautiful childhood,Thank you Bastila for showing how much the light side of human nature is stronger,Thank you Knights of the Old Republic

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Ok, the first time I played this back on Xbox, I didn't like the game.  I got used to button smash, hack and slash gameplay that I wasn't able to appreciate this game. I was young, I was stupid, and how wrong I was to not give this game a chance.This is my third playthrough, (the first two, I didn't even managed to play it for 2 hours and wasn't on steam), and HOLY MOTHER OF MERCY how good this game is.   The atmosphere, the feeling, and the twist, though I was spoiled on multiple occasions, but it is still good.  I'm not a fan of dice combat system, but somewhat I did not mind this on this game.  My thoughts right now are so scrambled because of how great this game makes you feel.  The environment is greatly implemented witrh complimentary colors.  The music is great, and it really makes you feel great playing as the Light Side Jedi, but nonetheless, this game has flaws sadly :(One great flaw are the bugs, it still is a buggy game, there are quest that you can't finish (you might need a save editor to finish it) and it sucks playing as the dark side.  I feel like they just throw that in for laughs, it's funny playing as the dark side jedi, but it doesn't give you the feel like you are bad at all.  Sometimes you get stuck, good thing for switching to other characters which helps fix that bug, videos are outdated, and yea. Idk, anyway it is a must buy play game.  I regretted not playing this throughly before and I'm happy I'm almost done with the game (beating LS side). It has a lot of replayablility if you are willing to try all the classes and which one works for you and etc. Anyway, one big tip is to read some guides for an easier battle and just enjoy the story it provides.I didn't read any guides and just keep placing feats and powers to my whim and I had difficulty in certain missions, you also had to control all 3 characters like you do on Dragon Age or you'll have a bad time.  Like I said, read guides first it helps to be honest.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
 Includes slight spoilers for some main and side-quests; I played through the game at least three times before I purchased it on Steam  Knights of the Old Republic - Review You are going to hate Knights of the Old Repbulic no matter how much enjoyment you gained from playing it. There is one simple reason for this: The moment the credits roll, you’re going to realize you just finished one of the best games ever made. And this can never be undone.4000 years before the battle of Yavin: You wake up aboard the Endar Spire amid a battle against a Sith-Fleet. Just like you, your character has no idea what the hell just happens and where he is. But behold, there is the unsung hero Trask Ulgo who is kind enough to explain the situation and the basics of the game. This is how the best Star Wars game ever created starts. From a modern point of view, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic might seem outdated. Its graphics pale in comparison to recent roleplaying games like the Mass Effect, The Wichter or the Dragon Age Series (all these titles are great in their own regard). But fancy graphics don't matter. KotOR puts heart and soul into its characters, plot and ultimately its dense atmosphere. And in one swift stroke BioWare pulls off what George Lucas never managed to do with the prequels: To tell a story of grand scale that is nonetheless personal and adventurous. Simply put, it creates a story that lives and breathes the original Star Wars. But you don’t need to be a huge Star Wars fan to adore this title as it is a great RPG, too. If you enjoyed Mass Effect or Dragon Age, KotOR is for you. The roots of the former titles can be traced back directly to the latter. Elements that were introduced in KotOR were later refined in these games. Your character is mute (just like in original Dragon Age). Every other character is fully synchronized. Some people are bothered by this and I can fully understand that but it offers the advantage that there are a lot more dialogue options than the recent BioWare-ian triad of “good”, “neutral” and “evil”. And, of course, this helps to bring some of the most memorable characters of video game history to life. You might’ve guessed it: The characters of this game are just amazingly well written. Every one of them brings something different to party. Every one of them is unique. And every one of them is memorable. I still can recall dialogues with every party member and that is no incident. Conversations are the beating heart of Knights of the Old Republic. Especially the ones with your crewmembers are excellent. Sometimes, they are dramatic. For example the quest that revolves around Bastila Shan’s parents. Other times they are hilariously funny – especially the conversations that involve a certain droid. Even the banter between your party members during missions is well written. BioWare manages to create some of the most beloved characters of the Star Wars Universe and with that they shaped the so called “Expanded Universe” for years to come. Credit must also be given to the beautiful voice acting by everyone involved. Naturally, this is also connected to the excellent storyline which offers one of the most shocking plot twists ever created. But truth to be told: The mission goals might get a bit repetitive during the mid-game. Nevertheless the steps to achieve the goal vary stark due to highly entertaining side-quests and level-design. For instance, during one main quest you are accused of a crime and have to defend yourself. If you do something wrong, they'll sentence you to death. In another mission you have to finish the training to become a Sith. Furthermore your quest leads you to highly diverse planets from the vast deserts of Tatooine to the tightly populated planet of Taris with its urban vibe that is reminiscent of Coruscant. The tremendous score by Jeremy Soule just enhances the experience - he carefully mashes up well-known tracks from John Williams with his own arrangements to create a unique soundtrack, that is deeply rooted in the realm of Star Wars compositions and yet highly distinguishable (listen to Bastila Shan's theme for reference).Besides the old-school-graphics, the gameplay probably discourages most people from picking it up. Admittedly, it’s slow as it is round based. That means you have choose an action your character takes after the enemy “finished his round”. It’s nothing like Mass Effect where you are actively aiming and shooting. If you want to boost the challenge, you stop using the pause button and choose an action for every party member. You don’t have to, though. The game is not very hard if you just want to enjoy the story. However, some boss fights can be really annoying on the first try.If you think about playing Knights of the Old Republic, do yourself a favor and just do it. You won’t be disappointed. If you generally like BioWare games or Star Wars you should play this as it was a defining game for the former and the latter. Tl;dr: KotOR combines a cast of great characters, a compelling story with some unpredictable twists and turns with polished gameplay. Conclusion: Play it, meatbag.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I got this game from my grandma for Christmas when it released. I never really had any experience with RPG games and I was really young but I could understand the dialogue well enough to love it. I'm still very young today but back then, the game felt so epic and HUGE! I felt like each planet would take days to finish when in reality it only took a few hours. This was the only game I would ever play, I had to have replayed it over 40+ times and this isn't an exaggeration! Once KOTOR 2 came out I just had to get it, the game was fun but not as memorable as KOTOR 1. I remember being actually scared at points in this game. When I arrived to Malachor V, I literally was frightened to play it. The atmosphere and music was so grim and well done! Yesterday, I found my original XBOX along with both games, I checked my save files and WOW, did I play a lot of this game. The music is so nostalgic and a masterpiece! I decided to replay both games and it still holds up today as my favorite game of all time! KOTOR will forever be in my heart.﻿ I could write an entire 5 page essay on the game because of so much more I have to say about it. But I'll leave it at this, and I highly highly encourage you to try out this game. It may seem kind of stale to todays standards, but back then, it was next-gen. This was the only game that I played in my childhood, and I probably played it for 4 years straight without ever getting bored of it. Please give this game a chance and even the sequel the same. One other thing I would like to mention is how emotionally invested in the characters you can get into this game. I was attatched to multiple characters and they felt like they were my friends in real life. I haven't ever had this feeling until recently, with the masterpiece "The Witcher 3", and honestly, it's amazing.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2012
												I tend not to play RPGs or at least keep a distance or ignore them in any way possible. They are out of my comfort zone and I can do nothing about it,  I'm too scared, too frightened to fire it up and it is especially hard for me to start such a long journey and commit myself to +40h of story. But at the same time I adore RPGs, I love them with all my heart and I love that they make me feel the way they do.I was thinking about playing KOTOR but I never had a chance to. I heard a lot of positive responses over the years of its existence so I got it on Steam Sale. This is one of the most prominent representatives of RPG genre with great story telling, one of the most unexpected plot twists I've ever seen implemented in a video game, 6 different planets for you to explore filled with side quests, loot, lightsabers and other shenanigans for you to find. It features excellent character skill tree and "d20 roll" system (named after the iconic 20-sided dice) which seems the most honest one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
												Its an old game that requires alot of work to get running these days, many people who review this game negatively for technical problems have not bothered to attempt to fix any issues they encounter. With that in mind here is an honest run down of some things in it.Every character is exposition dump. Every character is a cliche. Every character keeps me smiling.  Its a bioware rpg so i guess ye. Combat system is old dnd ish. Turn based realtime combat. Can be satisfying with the thud of three lasers hitting a single target all at once dropping it instantly. Generally the combat sounds and looks good for its age, cwl dueling animations.In terms of gameplay its very easy to manage and is only a problem on sand♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥planet (sry for edge cant spell it) due to level scaling enemies meaning you are swarmed by large numbers of tough asf sandpeople. (do it first)Force powers are cool to use but are comparable to spells u might see in a standard rpg really- Not that they dont appear fitting of star wars- just that the system is the exact same. Nice plot and companions, as well as the Darth Revan ofc being one of the most loved EU characters .  The second game gives us far more ♥♥♥♥♥♥y exposition regarding him that to me is cwl asf. (Is a Starwars Alexander the Great or maybe a starwars Rand al'thor/Matt?). Companions give you that good old exposition dump. However there is plenty of snappy dialogue and plot lines to chase with them. Canderous has some passionate stories for you. Mandalorians have some cool♥♥♥♥♥ships.If you have played the original dragon age- then expect a similar formula for how the game rolls.Finally- the music in this game is top tier... The opening theme for the game Endar Spire is amazing and the level is maintained from this game to the next. This ties in with the overall star wars atmosphere and universe building. Lots of details are filled by the heavy winded exposition. At the same time the atmosphere/music creates powerful dialogue and moments sometimes.  POTENTIAL SPOILERS "They say the Force can do terrible things to a mind.  It can wipe away your memories and destroy your very identity. "shiiitttttOverall if you are willing to troubleshoot the game or perhaps buy it from GoG, deal with biowarerpgitus, aged graphics and aged battle mechanics you will find an atmosphere that breathes awesome and characters that go down in star wars history as the best!If u want an idea of the emotional music or kick♥♥♥♥♥music see belowEmotional: 


YouTube™ Video: Star Wars: KOTOR 2 Music- Korriban/ Ravager Ship 

			Views: 65,877		

			Music from the video game Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic 2: The Sith Lords.		

Kickass Intro: 


YouTube™ Video: Star Wars: KOTOR Music- The Sith/Endar Spire 

			Views: 558,540		

			Music from the video game "Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic".		

If you were able to read this please tell me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												Over 10 years later and this game is still well worth the money. The combat is a little dated and might take some getting used to but the story, companion characterization and voice acting are top notch. Each area feels new and unique and you can feel the progression of your character as you move through the story.If you  have managed to avoid major plot points thus far I strongly recommend not reading anything else about the game. You're in for a fun ride.I had a couple of minor technical issues running this on Windows 10 but if you don't mind doing a couple quick google searches for problems you encounter (controlled character getting stuck after combat, ect.) you should have a relatively easy time.If you are someone who gets hung up on aesthetics (the game came out in 2003, cut it some slack) or are unwilling to do basic type and click research this may not be the game for you as you most likely will have to fiddle with some of the graphic settings to get things running smoothly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Don't be fooled by my Steam playtime. This was the RPG that got me into RPGs (narrowly beating out Morrowind) and when I was young I played through the game in every single way possible on my Xbox. Best birthday gift my grandmother ever gave me.If you enjoy any RPG or story rich games, this is an old gem from the 6th generation that is worth revisiting, even if the graphics don't hold up anymore. The story is amazing, to say the least, and shot Bioware to fame; without KOTOR who knows if they would have made Dragon Age or Mass Effect? If you like those two latter titles, KOTOR is clearly the blueprint of success that Bioware has been building upon in all of their other titles.It is sad that KOTOR II was sent off to Obsidian and that the MMORPG they made have failed to reach the original game's stature, but it is a very large shadow to fill.Bastila and Carth, Malak and Revan -- the characters are very well developed and the voiceacting is still great (and especially for the time period the game is from).The game is so good I bought it on Steam just so I could review it. Give it a shot and you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Bioware RPG's always have a special feel, and they are great to play.I finished this game a second time now, the first time I played it was as it was fresh and mint out of developement. Now, so many years later it hasn't lost it's apeal. The story and it's developement, the many hints that can give you the creeps - and still keep you guessing. Once again a good roleplaying game under the licence of Lucas Arts: Star Wars Trademark. Graphically dated, but yes there is an upgrade downloadable, there are also some unofficial mods to this game. The game itself is sealed in its story, there is no need to bugger around a lot - because the riddles and minigames are selfexplanatory. Being a Jedi can be quite a hard job at times... Decissions, decissions, decissions... and though some decissions can be quite deadly, others are more aimed at your preference about light and darkness. This time I decided to become a paragorn of the Light side... and, well, let's just say "Revan" died this time once and for all.Being a Jedi doesn't mean that you can't use subterfuge or clandestine ops - but you have to make sure that you help others with it, helping out a young couple just to press their families and them out off their money, isn't a good way to start.Off course, the game plays in a time far beyond the main story of the original films of the second and "first" triologies - but, it's still Star Wars and it does play a lot like a Star Wars game - running through the windblown and forlorn dunes of Tatooine, you could quite well feel the "vibes" of things to come in the future.I can recomend this game on several reasons: It's a Star Wars game. It's a Bioware RPG. It has a lot of depth and is an immersive experience. And Lastly it's Star Wars...Have I forgotten something? Probably, but for this it's just no rocket science.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The greatest Star Wars video game ever made.  The gameplay is fantastic and the story is an epic matched only by the original trilogy.  4,000 years before the movies you find your self in the middle of a galactic war between the Sith Empire and the Republic.  It falls to you and your rag tag band of scoundrels to find out how Darth Revan and Malak, heroes of the Mandalorian War and saviors of the Republic, fell to the dark side and raised a fleet large enough to invade the galaxy they just saved.  Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic will remind you why you fell in love with Star Wars.  Prepare yourself for drama, action, betrayal, love, and the Force as you move to decide the fate of the galaxy for the Light or the Dark.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												"Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic" is possibly the most immersive RPG of all time, in my opinion. The story is fantastic, bringing new, memorable characters into the Star Wars expanded universe. (Not to mention an unexpected plot twist) The gameplay is top notch, my only issue being how your character(s) maneuver(s), but you can easily get used to that small problem.  The worlds are rich and detailed, and there are many, many sidequests for very real-feeling characters. Lovers of Star Wars will love this game. RPG lovers will love this game. Lovers of great games will love this game. Words cannot describe how much I love this this game. One of my favorite gaming experiences of all time. -Sgt. Shy GuyOh, and developers ... The sequel isn't on Mac (which I use) so ... Wink, wink. Hint, hint. Nudge, nudge. XD

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												(I may only have 5 or so hours on this but I have the game on disc copy and burned out my first set of discs so I've played a ton)This is in my opinion one of the greatest games ever made, definatlly one of the best RPG's everIt is a game that fits amazing character interaction and plot development, into a world where you can more or less explore as you wish. You are not tied to your main character, if you want you could use one of the party memebers you meet as the character you control even.Combat is unuiqe, a mix bettween RTS and Turn Based at the same time, allowing for fast paced action or slow methodical planning, which ever you prefer.One of the things I liked is that there is a stat measure of your light or darkness, and your choices determine where that falls. If it's too light certian options are closed to you, or vice versa.My only complaint with this game is that it's old, so the graphics aren't the best, and it doesn't support modern resolutions; a fairly small complaint for a game.Overall I'd say KOTOR is worth the $10, probobly even worth twice that.Now what're ya waitin for, go get it, and don't forget to load up your atro droid with flamethrowers and take control of 'im XD

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Bioware RPG's always have a special feel, and they are great to play.I finished this game a second time now, the first time I played it was as it was fresh and mint out of developement. Now, so many years later it hasn't lost it's apeal. The story and it's developement, the many hints that can give you the creeps - and still keep you guessing. Once again a good roleplaying game under the licence of Lucas Arts: Star Wars Trademark. Graphically dated, but yes there is an upgrade downloadable, there are also some unofficial mods to this game. The game itself is sealed in its story, there is no need to bugger around a lot - because the riddles and minigames are selfexplanatory. Being a Jedi can be quite a hard job at times... Decissions, decissions, decissions... and though some decissions can be quite deadly, others are more aimed at your preference about light and darkness. This time I decided to become a paragorn of the Light side... and, well, let's just say "Revan" died this time once and for all.Being a Jedi doesn't mean that you can't use subterfuge or clandestine ops - but you have to make sure that you help others with it, helping out a young couple just to press their families and them out off their money, isn't a good way to start.Off course, the game plays in a time far beyond the main story of the original films of the second and "first" triologies - but, it's still Star Wars and it does play a lot like a Star Wars game - running through the windblown and forlorn dunes of Tatooine, you could quite well feel the "vibes" of things to come in the future.I can recomend this game on several reasons: It's a Star Wars game. It's a Bioware RPG. It has a lot of depth and is an immersive experience. And Lastly it's Star Wars...Have I forgotten something? Probably, but for this it's just no rocket science.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2012
												Statement: The RPG that made Bioware famous to non-PC gamers may have one of the most spoiled game stories ever. Spoilers are why I didn't finish for 9 years, and much like ESB, the impact is less if you know ahead of time. But KOTOR isn't just one of the first great Western console RPGs.Explanation: In 2003, two Star Wars prequels & The Matrix Reloaded left many dejected. This was the blockbuster people WANTED. There had been Star Wars games before, but here was a setting wholly untouched by George Lucas. Though much is evocative of the original films, many of the NPCs are rough drafts for Mass Effect's.Observation: The setting hides many of Bioware's now-maligned shortcomings; here the binary morality makes sense. The "Bioware romance" can't really come into full effect either. But sci-fi trappings aside it's literally D&D for all the clunkiness that entails. I grew up on Baldur's Gate, so I can deal.Conclusion: The assassin droid HK-47 is the greatest. Play for him, meatbags!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2012
												An amazing game from back in the early days of Bioware. The twist right near the end I never saw coming in that way Bioware have always been in great story telling. Apart from when they seemed to have become one with EA and messed things up, but I digress.Game starts where the republic ship you are on is under attack from Sith fighters and you have to make your way off the ship, battling your way through sith soldiers and getting to an escape pod where the real meat of the game begins on the planet of Taris.The game is based on the 3rd edition roleplaying game so if you have any experience with D&D you'll have no trouble getting into this game. As i said before, it's classic Bioware with the great storytelling and characters that are so realistic and you end up caring about. You get the chance to become either a Jedi or Sith. Both sides have different types of powers that can be used in many different ways. This is a game I highly recommend for it's story-line and replayability.

The problem is: they're ripping you off with outdated software that has a TON, and I mean A TON of glitches, specially regarding widescreen: sometimes you get it right after hours of tweaking, or you don't.Moreover, it's problematic that many people have served this purpose by recommending this game's steam version (completely not worth the cost) out of pure nostalgia and emotions. If you're thinking about buying this game, I certainly wouldn't recommend you getting this at least here unless you'd love to have it on your library or something. I think it's encouraging companies to be lazy and rip you off with overpriced, non-physical and problematic game engines.Of course, the game itself is amazing and one of the best Star Wars and Bioware games ever, but you're gonna find it hard to adapt this to your specifications.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												I've attempted to play this game 4 times. Every time I hated it, but now I love it.When I first played this game I liked Star Wars, I was interested in it alot. I wasn't very patient and I really never gave it a chance. Now I love Star Wars, and I gave it a chance and it was amazing, by far one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played. It takes a while to get past the boring start, but once you really get into the campaign the story is so gripping and exciting.This game is years old, but has aged well along with Battlefront 2. May the Fourth be with you sale is active right now, so you can get this game pretty cheap, along with any other Star Wars game on Steam.I've had the entire collection for a while now, but I would recommend this game to any Star Wars fan.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												Cons:- Bugs, mainly movement ones, are dime a dozen. You WILL die more than once because your char pathfinding suddenly decided to go on holidays, or he decided that actually casting the Force powers you told him to wasn't all that important, or will be bodyblocked into a corner by your own team mates, or conversely they will somehow get stuck hundreds of meters away.- The light vs dark struggle is about as angsty and childish as you remembered it. "Omgerd, the jedi council is manipulating you", "The dark side is stronger" *proceeds to get his♥♥♥♥♥kicked* and other moustache-twirling bigotry abounds. In several instances, you get card-carrying villains right away. The sith doesn't even seem consistent about if they want to be openly evil, or just emo.- Clunky combat system interface. It could have done with 16 shortcuts assigned to keys. Instead you have 5 or 7 that you have to click manually to use or cycle.- Much running from one place to another without possibility to fast travel most of the time.- The special effects, combat movements and other graphical fireworks aren't anything to write home about... Obviously you have to take into acount that this game wasn't made exactly yesterday.- The aliens talk gets quite annoying after a while, specially when you realize that the alien has spoken the same phrase 3 times to  say completely unrelated things. Surprisingly, some important dialogues are handcrafted even if they are spoken in alien language.- The inventory UI in general suffers from both overcrowding and lack of information. My guess is that this is due to the game being developed in a time when lower resolutions were the norm. Today, most screen space goes painfully unused.Pros:- The feats, powers and other char-building attributes system is both engaging and understandable, it being pretty much a D&D 3.5 clone.-The game is about 40 hours long, which is quite good in my book. It has lots of sidequests, some of them rather irrelevant, some others can take you half an hour.- Most party-member characters are interesting and I pitied not being able to take all of them and see their dialogues.- You can visit the planets in any order you want, and many characters will have extra dialogues depending on which you have and which you haven't visited yet.- The plot itself is somewhat interesting. Not spectacular, but interesting, as far as the Star Wars franchise goes.Overall: I would give it a 8 out of 10, even compared to today's games. Despite the obvious flaws that more recent games have learned about and corrected before they hit the market, this game is still quite enjoyable and worth finishing. Maybe even replay it in the future.Addendum:Honestly, this whole sith thing makes no sense. I know it's just a fantasy world, but it's really stretching my suspension of disbelief when the world basically runs on:1. The siths being viable only because the evil guys comply with their principles. Literally. There's no reason why there couldn't be 2 siths fighting against eachother, but every single character in the universe seems to have come to accept that if there's a sith lord, then every other sith is at his command. Period.2. Which creates rather dumb situations. I'm growing tired of this whole "I tortured you, so you now have to serve me" "Why?" "He... uh... because... dark side, you know". Why the hell would any apprentice, let's say Bastila in this case, become the bad guy's wilfull servant, instead of stabbing him on the back 5 minutes later out of revenge?3. Unless of course, you argue that they've been brainwashed. Which makes it it's own kind of fun, considering that every fallen jedi ever loves to whine about how the jedi council has brainwashed you and how they seen the light (or the dark) of how much more strong the dark side is.4. Right after which you proceed to kick their collective asses repeatedly. All while they keep claiming that they are stronger. Nevermind that the only way they have grown strong is *because* people is buying into the collective lie. If people didn't *think* the siths are stronger, they wouldn't enlist, and the siths wouldn't be strong. This is basic sociology.5. Instead, in this universe whole armadas seem to turn to the dark side for no specific reason other than "today I woke up and I was evil". Because, much like the existence of the sith, apparently the existence of the dark side depends on people despairing over their own perceived fall to the dark side. I blame the Jedi masters for their never ending crap about how you will fall to the dark side if you do this or that. Obviously they make people fear their own feelings and think they've crossed a point of no return as soon as they have a spark of feelings.

content:

												IMPORTANT NOTES:Most negative reviews are about this Steam version, Windows 10 and other tech issues. I can't speak for all, but here's a few things I found, and what worked for me:1. WIn 10 works fine for me with it - I just made sure the .exe runs as an admin and in XP SP2 mode.2. The lack of widescreen is frustrating, but there are a number of fixes that work. And I found one that was even simple to use. Getting widescreen definitely made it much more enjoyable.I just cannot give it a thumbs down for these things. Yes, it'd be nice to have them fixed, but I've seen worse hacks on Steam, and this still rates as EASILY one of the more enjoyable RPGs I've ever played. So 15 mins surfing and 20 or so minutes of farting around were definitely worth it. Still two thumbs up.An the best bit? Reuniting me with one of my earlier NPC crushes... when I was younger MAN how I wanted to use my special light sabre on Bastilla - I swear the things I was thinking were definitely from the dark side...

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												This is my number one game of all time, and I definitely don't say that lightly. I may not have a huge amount of hours on this, but that's only because I played this so much before it was on Steam. It's not perfect, but then no game is without faults. I love everything about the Star Wars expanded universe and this is the pinnacle of it, it rises high above the waste and filth that are 90% of Star Wars video games and stands proudly as an amazing story drive experience. Light Side or Dark side, you choose, it's all up to you and it will affect you're ending and which of your party members decide to stand with you.I'm not normally a fan of turn based combat, but they nailed it right here, the animations, the visuals and the effectsdo look quite dated now but believe me, at the time it was a sight to behold.It's hard to give this a neutral critical review because it would be like insulting my child if I were to say too many negative things against it. I cannot recommend this game enough. BUY IT WHATEVER THE PRICEPlus it has one of my favourite WTF moments in gaming.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
The Game I Spent Hours Exploring In My Younger DaysWow. When I was younger I was given this game. New to the RPG genre at the time, I played about 5 minutes and basically hated it. About a month later I decided to pick it back up. BEST DESCISION EVER. This game shaped what modern RPGs are. This game looked beautiful when it was new, and I had never seen anything like the massive amount of content inside it before. It was exactly as I remembered, and when I get some time, I'll sit down and play through a couple times. Of course I'll have to check absolutely every container and do every quest, but that's the great part.Good for nostalgia, or if you are craving a new adventure, you won't be dissapointed. 17/5

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Forget George Lucas's prequel trilogy, the best Star Wars story to take place before the events of A New Hope is Knights of the Old Republic. Of all the Star Wars games I have played over the years this is still head and shoulders above the rest, both in terms of gameplay and narrative.Prepare to spend the next 40 hours exploring the galaxy with Carth, Bastila, and the wonderfully sadistic, HK-47. Even for an RPG this old there is so much scope within the game. Before becoming a Jedi you can opt to be a solider, a scout, or a scoundrel like Han Solo. Each has its benefits and its pitfalls but the real fun is trying a new one every time and seeing which one best suits you.So as HK-47 would probably say, "statment: do yourselves a favour, meatbags, and buy this game". Although KOTOR II was a solid sequel, Knights of the Old Republic is still, not just the best entry in the series but, the best Star Wars game out there.

												I highly recommend this game for any Star Wars fan. Its a fun twist of visual novel and rpg elements. After picking it up I found myself emmersed in the story and the characters.
